story:
THIS is a really special one for us...

In 2014, we set out to tour the country with The Tale of a Town.

Our aim: to capture the collective community memory of our Canada’s beloved main streets.

Since then, this husband and wife duo, has toured all 10 provinces and 3 territories, gathering stories through interviews in our storymobile (a.k.a. recording studio on wheels) - with the exception of Nunavut, where we toured by ship.  

These recorded stories inspired the the creation of dozens of performances developed in collaboration with local artists , and presented in storefronts across the country.

Oh, and also along the way, our two sons were born, and joined the ride!

And now, we are beyond excited to present this piece that will feature some of the thousands of voices we have recorded from coast to coast to coast during this 3 year trek across the country in this epic family adventure.

THIS is ambitious...

The Tale of a Town - Canada travels with a team of 4 artists, and features local elements in each place where it tours, including a community choir, a home grown band, and local performers.  In addition, there is customized content derived from local interviews, to ensure the audience will be able to hear their own voices inside this national tale.

Engaging with the local community is important to us, but in order to realize this vision, there are added expenses incurred.

We have received funding from The Ontario Arts Council, The Toronto Arts Council and a presentation fee from each of our theatre partners, but we still need a bit more support to keep us moving.

Your contribution will go directly to cover the following expenses:

  • artist fees for local musicians and performers
  • honorarium for community choir director
  • artist fees for audio editors to pull together unique local content for each presentation
  • airfare and accommodation for the touring team to spend one extra week in each place engaging with the local artists

Where are we going with THIS?

  1. Oakville Centre for The Arts (ON)
  2. Fredericton Playhouse (NB)
  3. Northern Arts and Cultural Centre (Yellowknife, NT)
  4. The Esplanade Arts & Heritage Centre (Medecine Hat, AB)
  5. Theatre Passe Muraille (Toronto, ON)
  6. Milton Centre for the Arts (ON)
  7. FirstOntario Performing Arts Centre (St. Catharines, ON)
  8. The Grand Theatre (Kingston, ON)
  9. The Burlington Performing Arts Centre (ON)

-- with more dates to come.... in 2018/19

What is THIS, exactly?

  • It's a live theatre show that features cinematic video, puppetry, live music layered with audio.
  • It's a living archive of over 3000 interviews conducted in over 200 communities across the country.
  • It's a true story about our family and our epic tour across the country.

The Tale of a Town - Canada will offer our audiences the opportunity to hear stories from vast parts of the country alongside each other, juxtaposing voices from urban centres with those from less travelled places such as Labrador City NL, Prince George BC and Oyster Pond NS.  Songs and sounds collected from across the country accompany a range of voices like that of a 104 year old woman from Georgetown PEI, an elder from Churchill Manitoba, our first female mayor in Whitehorse Yukon, Acadians of Caraquet New Brunswick, and Inuit artists in from Cape Dorset Nunuvut, alongside local stories. Each presentation also integrates an acknowledgement of the land, as told by indigenous elders interviewed in each place who shared their knowledge with us for inclusion in this production.

Why are we doing THIS?

It is our deepest hope that as we put voices from disparate parts of Canada on stage and examine the history we have shared or failed to share, that this production will allow us to hear each other more deeply; to understand how we are different, and realize what we share in common in our sometimes fractured, sometimes connected country and the role our main streets and downtowns have played in the evolution of our communities.

How you can HELP MAKE THIS HAPPEN!

Every contribution will go a long way - literally.

And there are lots of perks to get.  Let us come help tell the tale of your family!  We'll make a podcast all about you!  And, truly, our crests are pretty cool... 

But if you can't donate, you can still contribute to our cause by spreading the word, coming to our show and telling your rich friends all about what we do.

In the 10+ years we've been running FIXT POINT, we've never sought out donations before.  But, since we need a little help, we thought we'd ask...

---Thank you for listening and we hope to hear from you soon! 

Lisa Marie DiLiberto & Charles Ketchabaw

Co-Creators of The Tale of a Town 

Artistic & Managing Directors of:

FIXT POINT.

Dream BIG, start small... 

PS - FIXT POINT is a registered not-for-profit charity, and can issue tax receipts for all donations of $20 or more!

story:
Celebrating Diversity...

The Boulder Dance Coalition - the group that runs the Avalon Ballroom - knows that dance is not only good for our well-being but can also be a powerful bridge to better human understanding. Our mission is to promote public participation in dance and music which is realized through the annual Boulder International Festival. Communities can pass laws intended to curb xenophobic attitudes. Groups can have candlelight vigils, stand in solidarity at protests, and write editorials. But when people hold hands and dance with one another, attitudes can change within individuals.

Each year, we depend on donations from festival goers and various grants to help offset the cost of the festival that has become a Boulder tradition since the original Folkfest in 1981. (click here for more history) As a 501(c)3 non-profit, our budget has limitations and so we are reaching out to the public in hopes of raising funds to help sustain and grow the Boulder International Festival.

At the Boulder International Festival you’ll find some of the best talent in the state representing many flavors of dance and music, with performances, dance teaching and an emphasis on participation. The festival also hosts a world market featuring local artists and fair-trade art, jewelry, and handmade goods from around the world.

This year's festival is June 15-17, 2018. The list of 2018 performers will be posted when finalized. In the meantime, check out the 2017 lineup!

 

But we can't do it without you...

The Boulder International Festival is a 3-day event, free and open to the public and all ages. Each half hour features a different dance performance, some with live music, ranging from cultural traditions of "village" life around the world to tango, waltz and Zumba demonstrations.

The festival kicks off with a public square dance led by Scootbacks Square Dance Club on Friday night followed by participatory international folk dancing with music by Barbelfish Balkan Band on Saturday evening with a variety of dance lessons and demonstrations from performers throughout the weekend.

To put this all together requires a budget of just over $10,000. We are hoping to raise $2,000 through crowdfunding to:

  • Provide the flexibility we need to focus our efforts on expanding the festival to include new audiences.
  • Ensure that we can continue to produce the festival.
  • Allow us to keep the festival FREE!

Here is a breakdown of the festival budget:

  • Location – space rental, electricity, restroom cleaning, permits $250.00
  • Advertising – flyer/poster design and editing, event promotion efforts $700.00
  • Printing – flyers, site maps, signage $650.00
  • Supplies – print/copy materials, postage, food $750.00
  • Staff – manager, staff, crew $3,500.00
  • Rentals – tent and chairs $1,650.00
  • Audio – systems, technicians, Saturday night band $1,800.00
  • Security – 2 security personnel for 2 nights $960.00

Each year local business and organizations help support the festival. The Boulder Dance Coalition thanks those who have already pledged to support the 2018 Boulder International Festival:

  • Boulder Body Wear
  • Boulder County
  • Boulder Daily Camera
  • City of Boulder
  • City of Boulder Human Relations Commission
  • Downtown Boulder
  • KGNU 88.5FM
  • Eldorado Natural Spring Water

Perks

BDC Friend – Everyone who contributes to the campaign will have their name added to the thank you display at the festival.

 

The Impact...

The Boulder International Festival promotes openness, diversity, inclusivity, and exploration - things that are good for our psyches and our communities, just as dancing is good for the body. Communities around the world are in need of unity, even in Boulder which has an educated, world-traveled, left-leaning population. There have been threats called in to the Jewish Community Center and racist tagging around town among other overt expressions of prejudice. Many of these intolerant opinions stem from lack of opportunity to get to know people from other cultures, and therefore we feel the festival is more important than ever.

We believe that if people hold hands and dance; actually experience the energy generated by participating in the brief experience of being inside the culture the change of attitude will happen from within the individual.

 

Other Ways You Can Help...

Even if you can't donate, please help us spread the word! Share this link and let people know about the Boulder International Festival and be sure to come to the Pearl Street Mall June 15-17 and dance!
story_txt:
Celebrating Diversity...The Boulder Dance Coalition - the group that runs the Avalon Ballroom - knows that dance is not only good for our well-being but can also be a powerful bridge to better human understanding. Our mission is to promote public participation in dance and music which is realized through the annual Boulder International Festival. Communities can pass laws intended to curb xenophobic attitudes. Groups can have candlelight vigils, stand in solidarity at protests, and write editorials. But when people hold hands and dance with one another, attitudes can change within individuals.Each year, we depend on donations from festival goers and various grants to help offset the cost of the festival that has become a Boulder tradition since the original Folkfest in 1981. (click here for more history) As a 501(c)3 non-profit, our budget has limitations and so we are reaching out to the public in hopes of raising funds to help sustain and grow the Boulder International Festival.At the Boulder International Festival you’ll find some of the best talent in the state representing many flavors of dance and music, with performances, dance teaching and an emphasis on participation. The festival also hosts a world market featuring local artists and fair-trade art, jewelry, and handmade goods from around the world.This year's festival is June 15-17, 2018. The list of 2018 performers will be posted when finalized. In the meantime, check out the 2017 lineup! But we can't do it without you...The Boulder International Festival is a 3-day event, free and open to the public and all ages. Each half hour features a different dance performance, some with live music, ranging from cultural traditions of "village" life around the world to tango, waltz and Zumba demonstrations.The festival kicks off with a public square dance led by Scootbacks Square Dance Club on Friday night followed by participatory international folk dancing with music by Barbelfish Balkan Band on Saturday evening with a variety of dance lessons and demonstrations from performers throughout the weekend.To put this all together requires a budget of just over $10,000. We are hoping to raise $2,000 through crowdfunding to:
Provide the flexibility we need to focus our efforts on expanding the festival to include new audiences.
Ensure that we can continue to produce the festival.
Allow us to keep the festival FREE!
Here is a breakdown of the festival budget:
Location – space rental, electricity, restroom cleaning, permits $250.00
Advertising – flyer/poster design and editing, event promotion efforts $700.00
Printing – flyers, site maps, signage $650.00
Supplies – print/copy materials, postage, food $750.00
Staff – manager, staff, crew $3,500.00
Rentals – tent and chairs $1,650.00
Audio – systems, technicians, Saturday night band $1,800.00
Security – 2 security personnel for 2 nights $960.00
Each year local business and organizations help support the festival. The Boulder Dance Coalition thanks those who have already pledged to support the 2018 Boulder International Festival:
Boulder Body Wear
Boulder County
Boulder Daily Camera
City of Boulder
City of Boulder Human Relations Commission
Downtown Boulder
KGNU 88.5FM
Eldorado Natural Spring Water
PerksBDC Friend – Everyone who contributes to the campaign will have their name added to the thank you display at the festival. The Impact...The Boulder International Festival promotes openness, diversity, inclusivity, and exploration - things that are good for our psyches and our communities, just as dancing is good for the body. Communities around the world are in need of unity, even in Boulder which has an educated, world-traveled, left-leaning population. There have been threats called in to the Jewish Community Center and racist tagging around town among other overt expressions of prejudice. Many of these intolerant opinions stem from lack of opportunity to get to know people from other cultures, and therefore we feel the festival is more important than ever.We believe that if people hold hands and dance; actually experience the energy generated by participating in the brief experience of being inside the culture the change of attitude will happen from within the individual. Other Ways You Can Help...Even if you can't donate, please help us spread the word! Share this link and let people know about the Boulder International Festival and be sure to come to the Pearl Street Mall June 15-17 and dance!

story:
EG Cohen Medal Foundation Seed Funding

Hi Phil Gresley here. I am sure my grandfather (and father) would both have been so deeply proud of seeing everyone come together and enjoying themselves the other night on the rooftop.

Sophie, Daniel and I are very excited about the positive response you have shown us (and each other) and are energetic about progressing the ideas discussed on the night.

We believe that you medal winners are a bunch of like-minded people wanting to contribute something extra into our architectural world.

We see the EG Cohen "foundation" (or however we end up defining ourselves) as an exclusive group with an inclusive focus - spending energy inwards and also focused outwards to assist those in need by using our combined knowledge, experience, networks and skills.

We are quite unique for a group which has no obvious generational bias. This was wonderfully evident on the night. I listened to a great conversation between Tuan, one of our youngest members, and Michael one of most senior, discussing the "fourth industrial revolution". Super.

For those that were not able to attend on the night, all is not lost as there will be many more opportunities to catch-up. We also look forward to getting you on board with this exciting venture and trust you will consider throwing a few bucks into the kitty to kick things along!
 

What are the next steps?

We have had significant interest from medallists for joining the "board" but will be looking for more to get involved as time goes on.

Right now we are specifically looking to raise $4000 from our medallist group to put towards;

1) researching and implementing  the most appropriate model for a  formal organization, with appropriate governance structure including a "board" etc.

2) obtaining professional assistance in identifying funding opportunities, writing grants, and ultimately obtaining  funding to allow us to embark upon a range of activities related to the unique characteristics of the award - a sprirt of unselfishness.  See below.

If we all pitch in (say) $50, $100, or even $200 each we can easily raise enough money to get started. Due to our wonderful spread of "career age", its obvious that $100 can mean much more to some than others, so lets be generous in spirit with our younger members. There is also no pressure to give.

Some of our initial ideas to be explored should we obtain funding:

  • Mentoring / assistance / scholarships to underprivileged architectural students which might include indigenous, immigrant and other students who require help.
  • Embarking upon an education campaign about the importance of design, architecture and the built environment - to all levels of the education sector and possibly outwards into the broader public. This should also include educating students about what we actually "do" as architects.... We will look with a strategic focus and integrate into other possible programs / funding streams already in operation. Thanks Suzie Hunt for making us all aware of some future opportunities we may be able to explore in partnership with the AIA.
  • Providing assistance to immigrant architects who are qualified and hard working but may have trouble entering into the workplace due to language, cultural or other barriers (thanks David Hartree!)
  • The medallists could become a valuable "resource centre" for each other. 
  • The group consists of quite a number of well respected members of our profession and there is opportunity the group to become an advocate for issues that members consider important. A different voice from that of the AIA or the ACA and one perhaps crafted to be "thought leading" or "trusted advisor".
  • At the very least an annual get together to enjoy each others company and to introduce thew new winners! This could include the winners introducing themselves by way of presentation of themselves and their journey. We hope that being awarded the EG Cohen medal is somewhat exclusive and by entering into the group will provide an opportunity for members to provide knowledge, resources, mentorship and career assistance to the winners as they embark upon their careers.
  • If we don't reach our goal, we will have at least obtained funding to put together some catered events into the future to simply celebrate and enjoy each others company.

Please show your support!

Please also note that at this stage I have linked this campaign to an unused personal bank account. Upon the completion of the campaign this will be re-distributed into an appropriate account relating to the structure of the organisation.

story:
Short Summary

Founded by a Royal Academy of Music violin graduate, Lycaeum Music sought to fill in the gaps created by the cuts to the musical education provision in the UK. 

Music On Wheels is to be our flagship program for delivering music lessons, workshops, and concerts to some of the children that would otherwise never have the chance to experience them.

Lycaeum will contribute with £1800 toward this project every school month of 2019 and, with your help, we estimate that we will be able to introduce to music and teach over 8000 children in 2019. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need £15.000 to get the project going which will be used as:

  • £7000 for purchasing a 2nd hand bus
  • £3000 for refurbishing it
  • £3000 for purchasing the instruments onboard
  • £2000 for the initial running costs

For your contribution you will get various rewards ranging from a personalised 'thank you' letter and free passes to our events, to an entire day out on a picnic with the bus or having parts of the vehicle named after you.

 

The Impact

Playing music has been scientifically proven over and over again to be an invaluable and wholesome way for a children to develop their cognitive capabilities, as well as their artistic ones. 

You might have heard that 'love is the universal language of mankind' but music surely comes as a very close 2nd, with the same 12 different notes of the octave being understood across continents and cultures.

Our goal is to make this more accessible and affordable for as many children and adults as possible.

At Lycaeum we have so far taught 250 students privately in 2018, and have engaged with around 400 more through various community projects at Angel Central, St Pancras International, and at the Royal Academy of Music. With your help we can do so much more!

 

Risks & Challenges

So far we have overcome a number of challenges such as finding the bus to purchase and the people to operate it, as well as the tutors that will be giving lessons on it. 

Many more are yet to be overcome, such as permanent parking, security, refurbishment, and the instrument purchase, as well as securing possible deals with councils and businesses to cover the operational costs.

We are currently in talks with a number of private and public entities that have showed interest in supporting the project, and are confident that all the challenges will be overcome by February 2019. 

If we do not manage to get the full amount funded, we will be using the available funds to deliver comparable community projects without a vehicle.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

For those of us who can't quite afford to help us with a contribution, no worries at all!

If you believe this project will have a positive impact for the UK's children, please help us spread the word about the campaign! 

You can share it on social media or simply tell some friends about it.

Help us keep the music playing where it is needed most!

story:
Here's An Idea:

Join the Story, our collective story, by helping us a build an underground chapel from granite that will exist for 3000 years - at least. Ebenezer Chapel will use leading-edge innovations in architecture & design, engineering, acoustics and sustainability practices to hew a chapel underneath the earth that will become a place of prayer, meditation and hope for people from around the world.

Visitors will enjoy the lovely 6 acre park and then can then enter the chapel and begin the descent to the sanctuary. As you slowly walk the concourse, you'll be surrounded by natural light, raw granite and corten steel (see the perks about having your name engraved) until you are finally in the quiet of the chapel. Natural light will enter from a skylight and the walls will hold artwork representing Christianity and faith.

The sanctuary itself will hold up to 250 people and be a perfect place for weddings, large church groups, special events or just a place of rest for solitary travelers hoping to sit quietly in contemplation and peace.

TAKE THE ANIMATED VIDEO TOUR.

Learn more about the why, the concept & design, the team and watch a short video from the architect behind the chapel design, TEDTalk fellow, Xavier Vilalta. See other plans + maps of the site.

Developer Mark Boone has assembled a team to bring this chapel to fruition.
Mark Boone - our fearless leader - founded Markus Group Ltd., a Raleigh, NC based company that serves as a contract manufacturer for medical and consumer goods. He is no stranger to high technology manufacturing having spent nearly two decades working in the nuclear power and defense sectors.  

Xavier Vilalta is the founder and director of Vilalta Arquitectura, and despite his youth, he is already a distinguished international architect specializing in sustainability and innovation. His work combines leading edge technology with local resources and culture to create contemporary designs that suit their environment. Before his firm gained eminence, he was an associate professor at ETSAB, Barcelona's School of Architecture, where he taught design and mentored graduate projects.

Ted Bartelt is a civil & structural engineer in Raleigh, NC and the President and Principle in Charge of Alpha & Omega Engineering. Ted's three decades of experience range from investigations of buildings, bridges, dams, and other types of structures to designing bridges, buildings, industrial facilities, equipment supports, concrete tilt-up design, flood studies, storm water impoundment design, erosion control design, water and sanitary system design, retaining wall design, concrete repair, parking lot design, general site development, project specifications, cost estimates, and construction administration.

Higini Arau is a master of acoustics in architectural structures and beyond. He is the Founder and Director of Arau Acustica - a professional acoustic engineering studio in Barcelona. For more than 40 years, the Arau team has worked in every aspect of architectural acoustics, civil and industrial engineering, and urban, industrial and traffic noise mitigation and design. 

Jordi Pascual is the coordinator of the technical team at AIGUASOL. Since 1999, AIGUASOL has provided innovative solutions in engineering and research to reduce the impact associated with energy consumption. Jordi’s focus as a building physics specialist is to optimize the energy consumption conditions for Ebenezer Chapel, which includes both lighting and thermal aspects of the space.

Andy Osterlund - is President and Lead Architect at Osterlund Architects. He has lived and working in architecture in Raleigh, NC since 1998, building and drawing from a broad base of project experience, including city-scale mixed-use development, retail, religious and institutional projects.

How YOU Join the Story

We're entering the 2nd phase of our project. Phase One included having the project endorsed by the city and engineering tests conducted to make sure that a chapel could be built underneath the park and 100 ft of granite. DONE & APPROVED. 

The next step is to conduct core sampling of the area designated for the chapel. Think of it as a granite biopsy. Our engineering team will use a 1.5 inch bit to drill down 100 feet -- in 20 foot sections -- so that we can review the layers of rock from top to bottom. These sections will give us the story of the rock itself and where the strongest points for excavation are and where to place the roof ceiling of the chapel based on our designs and the rock's strength.

It's a big step and we can't do it without you.

We're going for $40K which will allow for core sampling and site analysis.

$100K allows us to employ design services, as well.

$180 gets us into the design phase, after site analysis and design services.

$280K gets us started with construction documentation.
Finally, we need approximately $4M for construction.

What You Get For Your Gift

Imagine that your great-great-great grand-daughter decides to go to Ebenezer Chapel after learning that you were a contributor, Maybe she finds out that it's a place of faith and history. Maybe she discovers that Ebenezer means "stone of healing" and thinks, "I just want to go see what it's about." While descending from the park into the entrance to the chapel, her pulse slows and her eyes adjust to the light. She walks a little more slowly and then looks up to find your name engraved in the corten steel panels. Suddenly, you're connected in a way that would not have been possible. It's a little gesture of love from you to those you will never meet. 

It's also a gift to yourself in the present, because we hope to have the chapel completed by 2019.

For A Gift of
$10 - you will receive a public THANK YOU on our website and on social media
$25 - your name will be entered into the chapel book
$75 - you will receive part of the core sampling or the granite we'll remove to make the chapel
$150 - we will engrave your name into one of the corten steel panels that flank the ramp into the chapel (1 inch high)
$300 - we will engrave your name into one of the corten steel panels (2 inches high)
$1000 - you will receive a signed drawing of the chapel design from Xavier Vilalta
$3500 - you will be able to host an event at the chapel.

The Impact

... is as multi-layered as the granite itself. For starters, public places dedicated to faith are more important than ever. We want to celebrate the permanence of Christ in a world of planned obsolescence and at the same time practice inclusivity by creating a place where anyone, at any time, can come to rest, pray or meditate, commune with the gardens in the park or descend to the chapel for solitude.
Second, the Ebenezer Chapel team is using innovative design and engineering practices to create a chapel that will, upon completion, BE FREE FROM TECHNOLOGY. Imagine that.
Finally, we hope contributors and visitors will think of the chapel the way Americans think of their protected State and National Parks: as sacred natural places of beauty, purpose and sanctuary. Or the way that citizens worldwide think of cathedrals, natural wonders and sacred spaces... these are places to be visited and loved for millennia.
 

Risks & Challenges

This is a massive project, but we're off to a great start and with your help, we will get there much faster. Michelangelo looked at a piece of stone and said he knew to remove everything that wasn't David. We're removing all of the granite that is not the Ebenezer Chapel so that you and future generations of others can visit a public place of peace.
The excavation, engineering

    Other Ways You Can Help

    We hope that you'll make a contribution to this project, but we also want you to TELL EVERYONE YOU KNOW. Follow us on Facebook & Twitter, read our blog and consider contributing a short blog about your own experience of sacred spaces and faith, parks or great architecture and design.

story:
Positivity Through Dance

Slum Dance Africa is a project that started in 2015 by B-Boy Vick in Kibera, Nairobi. The aim was to engage the children and youth in the surrounding community with something positive that brings joy and keeps them active and away from trouble. From one small community hall in the heart of Kibera Slum Dance Africa has now grown to be a continent wide movement that brings dance and opportunities to urban areas around Africa. Slum Dance Africa continues to have several local projects that are training children and young people in dance and arts in Kibera and thus also providing employment for young artist involved in the Slum Dance Africa staff.

The biggest project of Slum Dance Africa is the international dance competition tour taking place annually. This year the tour will go through Kenya, Tanzania, Uganda, Rwanda, Congo and Burundi collecting the most talented break dancers around to participate to a one week dance camp and final battle in Nairobi in December 2019.

Slum Dance Africa goes around each country with qualification events and the 2 finalists of 1vs1 and the best 3vs3 crew will win a money prize and a fully covered travel to Nairobi for the Final week. All dancers, no matter their origin, gender, age, education or economical status are eligible to participate and compete to win.

Providing young dancers opportunities is step by step making dance, arts and culture more appreciated in their communities. Slum Dance Africa is offering a platform and stage for the young dancers to showcase their skills and acknowledges the hard work they are putting in to making it to the top.

The team of Slum Dance Africa consist of people passionate about dance, art and making a change.

 

B-Boy Vick - The Creator, The Boss and the Heart of Everything

Edwin Mokaya - The Artistic All-over Organizer and International Guest Coordinator 

B-Boy Rodger - The Leading Trainer & "On the Ground" Project Coordinator 

Mustapha "Moose" Haji - The Visual and Technical Genius behind the screen

Don Wilson Odhiambo - The Guy behind the awesome pictures

Oscar Human - The Manager and Trusted Advisor

Saara Saturo - Assistant Producer and Crowdfunding Coordinator

Grace Atieno - The Secretary keeping us all organised

 

Food, Beds and Bus tickets please!

With this campaign we are looking assistance to cover the remaining 30% of the costs that are yet missing funding.  Each year Slum Dance Africa has gotten bigger and better. Meaning that this year the Final Week in December 2019 will consist almost 40 dancers from 6 different countries.

Transporting all these dancers from their homes to Nairobi and back will be about 2000 USD (approximately 25-50USD/bus ticket/person depending on the country of origin)

Providing everyone a place to sleep for 7 nights will be about 4000 USD (approximately 15 USD/person/night)

Giving everyone three meals a day and water to drink during practices will be about 2500 USD (approximately 9 USD/person/day)

So in total we are looking to collect 8500 USD through this campaign to help transport, feed and accommodate the young dancers traveling for the Final Week. We are hoping to reach our goal with this campaign and thus ensure all dancers are able to participate and be comfortable in where they stay and how they eat. In case we remain under our goal, the dancers will share beds and only eat once a day! ;)  Or... we will find a way to work with what we have the best way we can, like we always do!

We have already secured a budget for costs relating to all six country qualifications (travel, accommodation, event organizing, money prizes) as well as the event organizing costs of the final week dance camp and battle (venue and equipment rent, prize money, guest artist facilitation, technique and marketing). We are happy to work with valuable partners and sponsors who share our vision and enthusiasm and are making the project come alive. With your help we will make it fly!

 

Why Slum Dance Africa is making a difference?

"Before I left home to Nairobi, my mom told me that I better win and come back with that prize money or otherwise I should
just stay wherever I am and find work. Am so happy to go home now and tell her dance is actually paying our rent now." - The winner of 1vs1 battle 2018 from Tanzania

"Slum Dance Africa is just simply about making kids and young people smile and happy by dancing!" - B-Boy Vick, The Founder

"I want to thank all of you as we have been together here as family, though even tomorrow we are going to start our journeys after the battle we stay together and we are together." - Participant from Rwanda

"Slum Dance Africa is the most commendable youth program that spreads positivity among the youth in the slum" - One of the previous year sponsors, Member of Parliament Mr. Ken Okoth

 

Overcoming all the obstacles!

The team of Slum Dance Africa is quite used to overcoming obstacles. Throughout the years many things have come on our way and we always overcome one way or another!

As cliché as it may sound "This is Africa" meaning, things do happen. And even more of a cliche "Hakuna Matata" meaning in Swahili no worries. No matter if it is a bus breaking down, immigration trouble, unexpected costs occurring, technique failing, power black outs, internet not working, flights delayed, schedules failing because of traffic jams we have done it all and know that there is no situation our team cannot handle with smooth and style!

 

Join the Movement!

We want you to join the movement and become part of Slum Dance Africa! It is easy and simple and you can choose your way of supporting our agenda. Do all of the following or choose the best way for you to join us:

1. Contribute how ever much or little to this campaign and help us reach our crowdfunding goal!

2. Follow us on Instagram, Like us on Facebook, Subscribe on YouTube and so on...

3. Next time you meet your friend tell them about this amazing project you know and show them our stuff!

4. Come and see the country qualification events according to the schedule published on our social media pages.

5. Be in December in Nairobi and come and see the Final Battle and Theatre Night.

6. Drop us an email or message if you have a suggestion what else you could do for us!

story:
WHAT AM I RAISING MONEY FOR? 

In this first round of fundraising, I am seeking support for the first nuAfrica micro-festival to be held in New York City in the Summer of 2020. The single day event will be a micro music concert x conference experience celebrating African creative contributions with a curated crowd of diverse industry professionals, investors, brands, artists and fans. The event will feature a panel discussion, live music from African acts from the continent and the diaspora, and community building workshops for the establishment of cross-continental connections and collaborative projects. 

Money raised from Indiegogo backers in the first round will go towards securing an event venue and creating marketing content for the event. Subsequent rounds of fundraising will fund the international travel of African music artists. With additional brand sponsorships and producer investments, I will fund collaborative projects for the event. 

 

WHY? 

With the recent global mainstreaming of African sounds, aesthetics, and cultures, there is substantial demand for embracing shared African heritage through the exploration of music. Africa is known for being rich in creative innovation and talent, and everybody wants in on the zeitgeist. Yet lasting legacies of colonialism and neocolonialism have limited Africa’s ability to compete in global trade markets, systematically excluding African artists from the global creative economy and its lucrative music industry. 

It’s time to disrupt this system towards African economic development. Creativity as a commodity can dictate where global capital flows. Multiple studies have shown that creative industries are key catalysts for income generation, job creation, increased export earnings, foreign exchange and investment, and the growth of leisure and tourism industries. These are important factors for a continent still reeling from its peripheral position in the global economy. Furthermore, Leveraging U.S.resources and infrastructure for African development is a radical subversion of traditionally exploitative world systems.  

 

NEXT STEPS

Although nuAfrica will host an annual event, the firm’s core activities will be to advocate for and consult on the creation of collaborative projects between multiple stakeholders. After the event, I will continue to build new relationships and leverage existing ones, seeking further investment for projects and programs that advance the interests and platforms for African artists in New York City and around the world. The long term vision is to create high-level interventions that can impact infrastructure on the continent and increase Africa’s share of the global creative economy.

 

ABOUT ME 

My name is Sibabalwe Mona and I am a social enterprise strategist living in New York City. I am driven by my passion for African socio-economic justice and development, and inspired by the creative contributions and cultural impact of Africans globally. 

Born and raised in South Africa, I hold Bachelor of Arts and BA Honours degrees in International Relations from the University of Cape Town, and a Master of Arts in International Affairs from The New School. I am currently studying towards a Master of Science in Nonprofit Management & Social Entrepreneurship. I am a 2018 Impact Entrepreneurship Initiative Fellow. 

I am the co-founder of Tropical Jawn, a cultural entrepreneurship enterprise with the mission of connecting New York City’s diverse black diaspora and exploring new opportunities for growth and collaboration. As a freelance strategy consultant for social enterprises that focus on the development of Africa and its diaspora, my diverse experience includes strategic nonprofit development, communications, event production, and project management. My portfolio includes being the Director of the 2018 New York African Restaurant Week Festival. I believe in African solutions for African problems, and the power of collaborative community-driven actions in creating global change. 

 

RISKS & CHALLENGES 

Funding & Access: African artists lament the barriers that keep them from their audiences abroad, including financial resources for travel and visa limitations. If I am unable to raise enough capital in subsequent fundraising rounds, the event’s musical programming will be compromised.

Collaborators: This event relies on cultivating relationships with multiple stakeholders across public and private sectors and creating community towards a shared goal. If no one believes in the impact potential of nuAfrica’s mission, the event may suffer.

Creative direction: Collaborating with new partners leaves room for disagreements about vision. Finding like-minded partners with a shared vision is important, although I am prepared to compromise and collaborate as much as possible towards the core mission of nuAfrica.

story:
Currently opening a new aviation museum near  Bucharest, Romania, at Clinceni Airfield, called Bucharest Aerospace Museum, a brand  new museum, with some airplanes already received as donation from Canada, USA and Germany. These are: SZD-30 Pirate glider from Jena Fliegerklub, Rutan Long-EZ from Toronto Airport, Piper PA-28 from Westerly State Airport, Rhode Island, USA, The logistics is needed to ship these aircraft from their location to Clinceni Airfield. I will use this funds to cover the shipping of these aircraft by ocean from their countries to the airfield in our country

 

This is the official website of the museum:  www.aerospot.eu/?lang=en

This museum has nothing to do with the actual one, the Military Aviation Museum ! It will be a separate museum, with other types of aircraft. I am planning to offer free flights to visitors.

 

Deschid un nou muzeu aviatic langa Bucuresti, la Clinceni, expozitia aceasta neavand nicio legatura cu actualul muzeu al aviatiei militare. Voi expune alte modele de aeronave, cu o alta istorie, din alte tari. Am de gand sa ofer si zboruri gratuite vizitatorilor. Aceste fonduri vor fi folosite doar la acoperirea cheltuielilor cu transportul maritim al aparatelor de zbor din locatiile lor actuale la aerodromul Clinceni.

Va rog vizitati www.aerospot.eu

story:
Short Summary

Points of Light is a DIY Lowell project, and a unique opportunity to bring cultures together to share a beautiful celebration of spring. DIY Lowell is a community-led initiative to create small-scale projects and events in Lowell. Community members submit, vote on, and implement ideas.

Why Pay Us?

Your contributions will be put towards purchasing lanterns and decorating supplies, ambient lighting and music, renting tables and paying cultural performers.

The Impact

This, along with other DIY let projects are completely run by volunteers and rely heavily on in-kind donations from programming partners. So there's tremendous person-powered energy behind this project but when it comes to purchasing supplies, paying for permits, insurance, and other logistical things we can always use help. For more information about DIY and to see community partners please visit the DIY website and the Facebook page for this event (listing sponsors—to shortly include, hopefully, YOU).

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't help us with money right now, you can help spread the word by sharing this campaign with your social media cohorts. Please consider coming to the event on April 22, and decorating a lantern, and supporting local efforts to celebrate our diversity and our city.

story:
Wer ist fairMATCHING und was machen wir?

fairMATCHING ist ein Verein aus 5 Menschen, der seit rund einem Jahr Arbeit suchende Flüchtlinge und Unternehmen gezielt vernetzt. Durch unsere Begleitung sollen engagierte Unternehmen unterstützt und Geflüchtete nachhaltig integriert werden.

Viele Geflüchtete bringen hohes Potential, Know how und vor allem großen Ehrgeiz mit. Sie haben ein Ziel vor Augen, das sie in ihrer neuen Heimat erreichen wollen. Weil die Ressourcen fehlen, um diese Menschen individuell zu betreuen, können öffentliche Arbeitsvermittlungsangebote oft keine Rücksicht auf die Kompetenzen und Wünsche der Bewerber nehmen. Dadurch wird Arbeit als Integrationsmotor abgewürgt und aus Motivation wird Frustration.

Wieso diese Kampagne?

Wir wollen unsere Arbeit weiterführen und unsere Strukturen professionalisieren, um noch zielgenauer arbeiten zu können. Auch nach einem Jahr ehrenamtlicher Arbeit haben wir aus öffentlicher Hand noch keine Unterstützung erhalten. Daher ist das Überleben von fairMATCHING nun von dieser Kampagne abhängig
 

Was haben wir mit dem Geld vor?

Mit 89.000 Euro könnten wir mindestens ein Jahr weiterarbeiten – da uns jede/r Einzelne und das individuelle Arbeiten und nicht die Masse an Vermittlungen wichtig ist, geben wir ungern „Erfolgsprognosen“. Aber vor dem Hintergrund der Learnings des letzten Jahres, dem Netzwerk, das wir bereits aufgebaut haben und die Bekanntheit, die fairMATCHING in Salzburg schon erreicht hat, gehen wir davon aus, mit 2 Fixangestellten im kommenden Jahr rund 40 Bewerber langfristig vermitteln zu können

Was bekommt ihr von uns?

In unserer bisherigen Arbeit haben wir jeden Helfer, Unterstützer und positiven Einfluss gerne und berechtigt extra hervorgehoben. Wir möchten, dass die Welt von jedem einzelnen Unterstützer dieser Kampagne erfährt und haben uns dafür ganz besondere Perks überlegt. 

Und wenn wir das Ziel nicht erreichen?

Wir werden jeden Euro in die Arbeit von fairMATCHING stecken und sind für unsere motivieren und qualifizierten Bewerber froh um jeden Tag, an dem wir sie unterstützen können. Auch wenn das Funding-Ziel nicht erreicht wird, arbeiten wir mit der Summe, die wir bekommen, so lange wie möglich weiter. 

Wieso ist unsere Arbeit so wichtig?

Unsere Wirtschaft, aber auch unsere Gesellschaft stehen vor einer enormen Integrationsherausforderung, die wir mit fairMATCHING angenommen haben! Mit einer Unterstützung übernehmt auch Ihr Verantwortung und ermöglicht eine nachhaltige Integration unserer neuen Mitbürger. Lasst uns gemeinsam dazu beitragen, dass die positiven Beispiele unüberhörbar werden.​
 

Wie kann unsere Arbeit helfen?

Um zu vermeiden, dass das Potenzial, die Ziele und Wünsche der Arbeit suchenden Flüchtlinge untergehen, ist eine individuelle Betreuung unumgänglich. Das ist natürlich zeit und personal-intensiv. Unsere Arbeit im letzten Jahr hat uns aber gezeigt, dass genau so die schönsten Erfolge erzielt werden und beide Seiten gleich von dem MATCHING profitieren.

Wir wollen in Zukunft noch mehr Kontakt zu fairen Unternehmen pflegen und unser Netzwerk sinnvoll einsetzen. Auch im Sinne der Bewusstseinsbildung, dass Diversität etwas Positives ist, das viel kreatives Potenzial freisetzen kann. Gelungene MATCHING-Beispiele sind die Motoren für eine solche Entwicklung

Wie kann man uns noch unterstützen?

Wir sind froh um jede helfende Hand und jeden Kontakt, bei dem wir anknüpfen können. Wenn Ihr also aufgeschlossene Unternehmen kennt und eventuell einen Kontakt für uns herstellen könnt, ist uns ebenfalls sehr geholfen! Auf unserer FB-Seite geben wir regelmäßig bekannt, welche Bewerber gerade auf MATCHING-Suche sind – auch Reaktionen darauf sind hilfreich

Die Arbeit von fairMATCHING wird in Zukunft noch wichtiger werden – helft uns dabei, weitermachen zu können, indem Ihr uns unterstützt und Eurem Umfeld von uns und der Kampagne erzählt!

In unserer bisherigen Arbeit haben wir jeden Helfer, Unterstützer und positiven Einfluss gerne und berechtigt extra hervorgehoben. Wir möchten, dass die Welt von jedem einzelnen Unterstützer dieser Kampagne erfährt und haben uns dafür ganz besondere Perks überlegt. 
Und wenn wir das Ziel nicht erreichen?
Wir werden jeden Euro in die Arbeit von fairMATCHING stecken und sind für unsere motivieren und qualifizierten Bewerber froh um jeden Tag, an dem wir sie unterstützen können. Auch wenn das Funding-Ziel nicht erreicht wird, arbeiten wir mit der Summe, die wir bekommen, so lange wie möglich weiter. 
Wieso ist unsere Arbeit so wichtig?
Unsere Wirtschaft, aber auch unsere Gesellschaft stehen vor einer enormen Integrationsherausforderung, die wir mit fairMATCHING angenommen haben! Mit einer Unterstützung übernehmt auch Ihr Verantwortung und ermöglicht eine nachhaltige Integration unserer neuen Mitbürger. Lasst uns gemeinsam dazu beitragen, dass die positiven Beispiele unüberhörbar werden.​ 
Wie kann unsere Arbeit helfen?
Um zu vermeiden, dass das Potenzial, die Ziele und Wünsche der Arbeit suchenden Flüchtlinge untergehen, ist eine individuelle Betreuung unumgänglich. Das ist natürlich zeit und personal-intensiv. Unsere Arbeit im letzten Jahr hat uns aber gezeigt, dass genau so die schönsten Erfolge erzielt werden und beide Seiten gleich von dem MATCHING profitieren.
Wir wollen in Zukunft noch mehr Kontakt zu fairen Unternehmen pflegen und unser Netzwerk sinnvoll einsetzen. Auch im Sinne der Bewusstseinsbildung, dass Diversität etwas Positives ist, das viel kreatives Potenzial freisetzen kann. Gelungene MATCHING-Beispiele sind die Motoren für eine solche Entwicklung

Wie kann man uns noch unterstützen?
Wir sind froh um jede helfende Hand und jeden Kontakt, bei dem wir anknüpfen können. Wenn Ihr also aufgeschlossene Unternehmen kennt und eventuell einen Kontakt für uns herstellen könnt, ist uns ebenfalls sehr geholfen! Auf unserer FB-Seite geben wir regelmäßig bekannt, welche Bewerber gerade auf MATCHING-Suche sind – auch Reaktionen darauf sind hilfreich
Die Arbeit von fairMATCHING wird in Zukunft noch wichtiger werden – helft uns dabei, weitermachen zu können, indem Ihr uns unterstützt und Eurem Umfeld von uns und der Kampagne erzählt!

story:
PLEASE BE AWARE THAT THE DROM SHOW IS SOLD OUT AND THAT NONE OF THE PERKS INCLUDE TICKETS TO THE BENEFIT.

Barbès needs your help. 

Barbès turned fifteen this past May 1st and we have much to be thankful for. We have been able to stick to our vision of presenting strong original music on a daily basis - regardless of genre, current popularity or even common sense. We are proud to continue to be the incubator to countless new projects and our sole wish is to keep doing so for many years to come. 

Times they have a-changed, however. Surviving as a small business in this new, re-branded Brooklyn has become a sometimes insurmountable challenge. The overall price of doing business has increased tremendously (higher rent, increase in the cost of goods, services, permits, insurance etc.. ) and we have accumulated a debt that our dwindling profit margin has made nearly impossible to manage: $50,000 owed to our bank and  $20,000  owed to our landlord – most of it for city services related costs that, over the past few years, have spiraled out of control.

Our landlord had thus far been understanding, but as the city has now placed a lien on his building, we are faced with a hard deadline: pay $20,000 by July 1st.

Our credit line has reached its ceiling and our personal credit doesn’t allow us to borrow any more. Barbès has no assets - our only assets are the musicians who have chosen Barbès as a creative home, and the Barbès audience that comes and supports them.    

So, we turn to you. Raising the full $70,000 we owe would insure that we stay in business for at least another five years - when our second lease ends. In this current economic and political climate, five years feels reasonably close to an eternity. Having a sounder financial base might even enable us continue longer, but we are still a few bridges away from that particular crossing.
Short of that goal - which we do understand might be overly ambitious - we do need to find $20,000 before July 1st... Every bit will help..

Of course, you’re probably asking yourself why you should help. It’s a fair question, and we may not have a good answer.  We do think that we’ve built a place that is different from any other - and that what we are adding to the Brooklyn cultural landscape is worth preserving.  On the other hand, times are indeed changing: we may have ceased to be relevant and may deserve the slow death that seems to be awaiting us.

We hope not. 

In any case, we do believe that for the past fifteen years, Barbès has played host to a vibrant community and acted as a laboratory for all kinds of new music. We couldn’t be prouder of what we’ve achieved and are thankful to all of you for being a part of it.  We have every intention of surviving for however long as we can - or at the very least until the end of our current lease, five years from now. 

Paying back our debt would insure just that - at least five more years of Barbes as we know it.

To thank you for your help, we will have a panoply of music offerings – mostly Barbès Records releases as well as a special concert to take place on June 9th at DROM - (details soon to be released).

The whole Barbès crew thanks you, and hopes to see you soon.

story:
What is the San Juan Drama Company?

¡Hola! The San Juan Drama Company, since 2010, has been home to hundreds of youth with the aspiration to become performing artists. Some of our young actors live in public housing developments while others come from middle class homes. This keeps them away from the streets, drugs and violence as well as uniting them in what they all have in common - their passion for the arts! 

During the last 5 years, we have produced over 20 theatre productions and have been able to work in different community service projects. Now we would like to expand our creative energies into television and film! 

That is why we will be taking 20 of our most talented youth to Mexico City for an intensive "acting for the camera" workshop in the exclusive M&M Studio (www.patriciareyesspindola.com) from July 16th till the 31st, 2017. 

We are currently facing Puerto Rico's largest economic crisis in its history but are working very hard so that this political situation will not affect our youth's dreams and goals.  

For example, our final fund-raiser will be in a few weeks. It will be our presentation of the musical "The Addams Family". It will be held at the majestic Teatro Tapia in Old San Juan on the 7th, 8th and 9th of July.  With the money remaining after production expenses,  we are aiming to  cover the tuition, some airfare tickets and hotel expenses for those most in need. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • Our goal for this campaign is $2,800. This will cover dinner expenses for the trip. This works out to $10 per person, per night for 15 nights. 
  • Once we reach our goal, the excess will allow us to add a cultural field trip and attend some of the awesome theatre productions that are currently being presented in the city.

In return for your generosity, we will be offering:  

  • Premiere tickets for our productions
  • Your name in the rolling credits of our film course video
  • San Juan Drama Club T-shirts
  • Personalized Thank You videos from our youth
  • Personalized letters from the group or your sponsored youth
  • Advertisement in our playbill
  • And other cool surprises that we're preparing for you!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We know some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Share our campaign with those who you think might be interested in our cause and mission!
  • Use our social media and let us know you're supporting us!
  • Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Twitter: @SanJuanDramaCo

Facebook: San Juan Drama Company

We cannot THANK YOU enough for taking the time to read up to here and for whatever contribution you can make! From all of us, and from the bottom of our hearts, we THANK YOU! ¡GRACIAS! ¡MUCHAS GRACIAS!

story:
WHY LGBTQ+ ASIAN AMERICAN EVENTS?

Hello! I’m CB Lee, author of the SIDEKICK SQUAD series. As a queer Chinese-Vietnamese American, growing up, I felt pretty isolated and unsure of who I was, as part of the LGBTQ+ community and growing up as part of multiple cultures. Maya Reddy states in the Mission Statement of the Gaysian Project, “When we are not seen, we are not known. That sense of loneliness is overpowering. Rarely are all Asian ethnicities recognized. And just as rarely are all identities of queerness celebrated, especially within Asian American representation.”  Representation is just a small part of this event—it’s about creating and fostering community.

 As a writer, I seek to tell stories that not only entertain but also inspire others and show inclusive characters who reflect the world we live in. In 2017, I curated the first iteration of this event in partnership with the Chinese American Museum, and was overwhelmed by the amount of amazing people who turned up for what I thought would be a modest reading and panel. Instead, the CAM courtyard overflowed with community and people who came together to see our performers, explore the exhibits and participate in a lively discussion. This year, with your support, I’m hoping to create a unique and enriching experience for the community, working with the Chinese American Museum and the Gaysian Project to encourage people to explore the amazing exhibits at the museum and also participate in an evening of discussion.

2018: CELEBRATING THE ASIAN AMERICAN LGBTQ+ EXPERIENCE

CELEBRATING THE ASIAN AMERICAN LGBTQ+ EXPERIENCE brings together queer identified artists, musicians, and writers in historic downtown Los Angeles at the Chinese American Museum for Lambda Literary’s LitFest 2018. CAM’s current exhibit “Don’t Believe The Hype: LA Asian Americans In Hip Hop” challenges and redefines what hip hop represents, specifically within the Asian American community and how hip hop itself allows for more exploration for gender and sexual identity, defying “traditional” expectations. But whose expectations shape our experiences? Our community, our parents, ourselves? What does it mean to be queer and Asian American and how does one experience inform the other? Lambda Literary and CAM invite you to explore the exhibit and join us for a panel discussion and performances by D’LO, NATHAN RAMOS, KAY ULUNDAY BARRETT, KITTY TSUI, ADDIE TSAI, MAYA REDDY, and moderated by CB LEE.

 

THE IMPACT

Community events like these are pivotal towards our understanding of ourselves and others, and offer a chance for people within the community to meet others, to validate their existence and to see that they are not alone in their experience. This celebration inspires and invigorates the culture of arts and creativity and also provides a way for people to connect and discover new creators and works to support. 

 

GOALS

 

EVENT LAUNCH

Organizing events like this requires investment in administrative organizing, donations to nonprofit venues, managing volunteers, and also paying for necessary expenses such as audio and visual equipment rentals, staging, lighting, parking, and providing honorariums for speakers. As working artists and creators, it is important to compensate people for their valuable time and to value their contributions.

DONATION TO CAUSES WE BELIEVE IN

Our goal is to raise enough funds to donate to our venue, the Chinese American Museum, a 501C nonprofit organization, and also three nonprofits we believe strongly in: Lambda Literary, CAPE, and the Trevor Project.

AN ANNUAL CELEBRATION AND MORE 

We also want to continue to curate this event annually, and expand and grow as a point of connection for our community, and be able to sponsor short films and more events like these.

 

HOW YOU CAN HELP

We have a number of ways you can support this event, regardless if you wish to attend the October 4, 2018 event in Los Angeles. We are collaborating with The Gaysian Project to sell t-shirts directly on their website, where the proceeds will go towards this event, and also a portion of the proceeds from their classic Thank U For Seeing Us Shirt.

 

Also, your support and donation would mean so much to creating this community event. We have a number of exclusive perks for IndieGoGo backers, including a special mentorship program, 1" diameter buttons, signed books, and special t-shirts and gift packages. Click on the right on each perk for more details. Any proceeds donated above our project goal will be donated to Lambda Literary, the Chinese American Museum, CAPE, and The Trevor Project.

 

ABOUT LAMBDA LITERARY & LAMBDA LITFEST

Lambda Literary nurtures and advocates for LGBTQ writers, elevating the impact of their words to create community, preserve our legacies, and affirm the value of our stories and our lives.
The second annual Lambda LitFest Los Angeles is a celebration of contemporary voices honoring and expanding on the rich, diverse tradition of LGBTQ writers and readers in the Southland. 

 

ABOUT THE CHINESE AMERICAN MUSEUM

The Chinese American Museum is a museum located in Downtown Los Angeles as a part of the El Pueblo de Los Angeles Historic Monument. It is dedicated to the history and experience of Chinese Americans in the state of California, the first such museum in Southern California.

 

ABOUT THE GAYSIAN PROJECT

Maya Reddy, the founder of the Gaysian Project, says, "The Queer Asian community exists but is not visible. We are not visible in Western Media or many other ordinary spaces, and, in my experience as a Queer Indian woman, it has made it difficult to find a sense of belonging or community.  When we are not seen, we are not known. That sense of loneliness is overpowering. Rarely are all Asian ethnicities recognized. And just as rarely are all identities of queerness celebrated, especially within Asian representation." This project was born out of a somewhat selfish desire to find a community and place of belonging as a Queer Asian. The Gaysian Project’s home website will serve as a hub for resources for the Queer and Asian communities. 

 

ABOUT CAPE

Since 1991, The Coalition of Asian Pacifics in Entertainment has championed diversity by educating, connecting, and empowering Asian American and Pacific Islander artists and leaders in entertainment and media. 

 

ABOUT THE TREVOR PROJECT

The Trevor Project is an American non-profit organization founded in 1998 focused on suicide prevention efforts among lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and questioning youth. Through a toll-free telephone number, it operates The Trevor Lifeline, a confidential service that offers trained counselors.

 

ABOUT THE 2018 GUESTS

 

D’LO

D’Lo is a queer/transgender Tamil-Sri Lankan-American actor/writer/comedian whose work ranges stand-up comedy, solo theater, plays, films and music production, poetry and spoken word. He is a co-producer for DisOriented Comedy (mostly female Asian-American nationally-touring stand-up comedy showcase).

His work has been published in various anthologies and academic journals, including: Desi Rap: Hip Hop and South Asia America and Experiments in a Jazz Aesthetic (co-edited by Sharon Bridgforth) and Troubling the Line: Trans and Genderqueer Poetry and Poetics.

D’Lo is the creator of the “Coming Out, Coming Home” writing workshop series which has taken place with South Asian and/or Immigrant LGBTQ Organizations nationally, which provide a transformative space for workshop participants to write through their personal narratives and share their truths through a public reading.

NATHAN RAMOS

Nathan Ramos is an award winning actor and writer. He most recently was a songwriter and Music Coach for Disney's Club Mickey Mouse, the reboot of the classic Mickey Mouse Club. He is a 2017 CAPE New Writers Fellow, and works as a Script Doctor for both independent and Hollywood Films. He wrote for Webby nominated 'The Station by Maker'. Nathan won the See Change 2042 National Playwriting Competition, and his play 'As We Babble On' will have a full production at East West Players in 2018. His plays have been workshopped and read at Oregon Shakespeare Festival, Artists at Play, and the LA LGBT Center's Renberg Theatre. His writing has also been featured in various publications, most recently Thought Catalogue. As an actor, he has been featured Regionally across the country, and Off-Broadway.

 

KITTY TSUI

Kitty Tsui is the quintessential Renaissance woman: author, activist, artist, actor, athlete. Her 1983 groundbreaking WORDS OF A WOMAN WHO BREATHES FIRE was the first book by a Chinese American lesbian; her second BREATHLESS – EROTICA won the Firecracker Alternative Book Award; her third, SPARKS FLY was penned by her alter ego Eric Norton, a gay leatherman. Her writing has been collected in over 70 anthologies worldwide and been published in German, Japanese and Italian. She has written for magazines and newsweeklies including The Bay Guardian, San Francisco Sentinel, Bay Area Reporter, Lambda Book Report, Chicago Outlines and The Advocate. Midsummer Night’s Press and Sinister Wisdom will reprint WORDS OF A WOMAN WHO BREATHES FIRE as a Sapphic Classic along with new poems from NICE CHINESE GIRLS DON’T in July, 2017.

Out since 1973, she was instrumental in the birth of the Asian Pacific Islander lesbian movement in San Francisco, an original member of the first Asian women’s group, famous for ethnic dish potlucks, and a member of Asian Pacific Sisters. Editor of Phoenix Rising and New Phoenix Rising, she was co-­founder of the first Asian American women’s performance group, Unbound Feet. She has been a keynote speaker at universities, community colleges and conferences; a panelist, a poet, a performer and a workshop presenter.

 

ADDIE TSAI

Addie Tsai has a Master of Fine Arts from the MFA Program for Writers at Warren Wilson College in Asheville, North Carolina. Her memoir, and in its place—: An Ode to Frankenstein, has been a finalist with The Cleveland State University Poetry Center, 1913 Press, and Pleiades Press. Addie writes poetry, fiction, and nonfiction. Her creative nonfiction has been published in Banango Street, Post Road Magazine, Pebble Lake Review, and The Collagist and her poems have appeared in Banango Street, The Denver Quarterly, Collective Brightness: LGBTIQ Poets on Faith, Religion, & Spirituality, The Collagist, BORN Magazine, NOON: A Journal of the Short Poem, Forklift, Ohio, American Letters & Commentary, and Yellow as Turmeric, Fragrant as Cloves: A Contemporary Anthology of Asian-American Women's Poetry, among others. Her fiction has appeared in The Feminist Wire.

 

KAY ULUNDAY BARRETTT

Kay Ulanday Barrett is a published poet, performer, educator, food blogger, cultural worker, and transgender, gender non-conforming, and disability advocate based in New York and New Jersey, whose work has been showcased nationally and internationally. Barrett's writing and performance centers on the experience of queer, transgender, people of color, mixed race people, Asian, and Filipino community. The focus of his artistic work navigates multiple systems of oppression in the context of the U.S. He has also served on committees, organizations, and collectives in attempts to serve communities that desire self-determination. His work and thoughts have been published in media such as Bitch magazine, POOR Magazine, Curve magazine, and PBS News Hour.

MAYA REDDY

Maya Reddy is a queer South Asian professional golfer and founder of The Gaysian Project—a collective focused on fostering and empowering community through queer Asian visibility. She is a professional ambassador for Athlete Ally, and wrote and extensively researched the implications of queer representation on legislation for her undergraduate thesis. She also spent 3 years working in Hollywood on the development side with the Mark Gordon Company and Night & Day Pictures. Passionate about fighting for queer and female inclusivity in sports as well as raising awareness about Asian and Queer Asian issues.

 

CB LEE

CB Lee is a bisexual Chinese-Vietnamese American writer whose novels include the Sidekick Squad series, a young adult science fiction adventure that follow queer teens who take on a corrupt government superhero agency, and also the fantasy Seven Tears At High Tide. Lee’s work has been featured in Teen Vogue, Wired Magazine, and Hypable.

Not Your Sidekick was a 2017 Lambda Literary Awards Finalist in YA/Children’s Fiction and a 2017 Bisexual Book Awards Finalist in Speculative Fiction. Seven Tears at High Tide was the recipient of a Rainbow Award for Best Bisexual Fantasy Romance and also a finalist for the 2016 Bisexual Book Awards in the YA and Speculative Fiction categories.
