The Gaysian Project’s home website will serve as a hub for resources for the Queer and Asian communities.  ABOUT CAPESince 1991, The Coalition of Asian Pacifics in Entertainment has championed diversity by educating, connecting, and empowering Asian American and Pacific Islander artists and leaders in entertainment and media.  ABOUT THE TREVOR PROJECTThe Trevor Project is an American non-profit organization founded in 1998 focused on suicide prevention efforts among lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and questioning youth. Through a toll-free telephone number, it operates The Trevor Lifeline, a confidential service that offers trained counselors. ABOUT THE 2018 GUESTS D’LOD’Lo is a queer/transgender Tamil-Sri Lankan-American actor/writer/comedian whose work ranges stand-up comedy, solo theater, plays, films and music production, poetry and spoken word. He is a co-producer for DisOriented Comedy (mostly female Asian-American nationally-touring stand-up comedy showcase).His work has been published in various anthologies and academic journals, including: Desi Rap: Hip Hop and South Asia America and Experiments in a Jazz Aesthetic (co-edited by Sharon Bridgforth) and Troubling the Line: Trans and Genderqueer Poetry and Poetics.D’Lo is the creator of the “Coming Out, Coming Home” writing workshop series which has taken place with South Asian and/or Immigrant LGBTQ Organizations nationally, which provide a transformative space for workshop participants to write through their personal narratives and share their truths through a public reading.NATHAN RAMOSNathan Ramos is an award winning actor and writer. He most recently was a songwriter and Music Coach for Disney's Club Mickey Mouse, the reboot of the classic Mickey Mouse Club. He is a 2017 CAPE New Writers Fellow, and works as a Script Doctor for both independent and Hollywood Films. He wrote for Webby nominated 'The Station by Maker'. Nathan won the See Change 2042 National Playwriting Competition, and his play 'As We Babble On' will have a full production at East West Players in 2018. His plays have been workshopped and read at Oregon Shakespeare Festival, Artists at Play, and the LA LGBT Center's Renberg Theatre. His writing has also been featured in various publications, most recently Thought Catalogue. As an actor, he has been featured Regionally across the country, and Off-Broadway. KITTY TSUIKitty Tsui is the quintessential Renaissance woman: author, activist, artist, actor, athlete. Her 1983 groundbreaking WORDS OF A WOMAN WHO BREATHES FIRE was the first book by a Chinese American lesbian; her second BREATHLESS – EROTICA won the Firecracker Alternative Book Award; her third, SPARKS FLY was penned by her alter ego Eric Norton, a gay leatherman. Her writing has been collected in over 70 anthologies worldwide and been published in German, Japanese and Italian. She has written for magazines and newsweeklies including The Bay Guardian, San Francisco Sentinel, Bay Area Reporter, Lambda Book Report, Chicago Outlines and The Advocate. Midsummer Night’s Press and Sinister Wisdom will reprint WORDS OF A WOMAN WHO BREATHES FIRE as a Sapphic Classic along with new poems from NICE CHINESE GIRLS DON’T in July, 2017.Out since 1973, she was instrumental in the birth of the Asian Pacific Islander lesbian movement in San Francisco, an original member of the first Asian women’s group, famous for ethnic dish potlucks, and a member of Asian Pacific Sisters. Editor of Phoenix Rising and New Phoenix Rising, she was co-­founder of the first Asian American women’s performance group, Unbound Feet. She has been a keynote speaker at universities, community colleges and conferences; a panelist, a poet, a performer and a workshop presenter. ADDIE TSAIAddie Tsai has a Master of Fine Arts from the MFA Program for Writers at Warren Wilson College in Asheville, North Carolina. Her memoir, and in its place—: An Ode to Frankenstein, has been a finalist with The Cleveland State University Poetry Center, 1913 Press, and Pleiades Press. Addie writes poetry, fiction, and nonfiction. Her creative nonfiction has been published in Banango Street, Post Road Magazine, Pebble Lake Review, and The Collagist and her poems have appeared in Banango Street, The Denver Quarterly, Collective Brightness: LGBTIQ Poets on Faith, Religion, & Spirituality, The Collagist, BORN Magazine, NOON: A Journal of the Short Poem, Forklift, Ohio, American Letters & Commentary, and Yellow as Turmeric, Fragrant as Cloves: A Contemporary Anthology of Asian-American Women's Poetry, among others. Her fiction has appeared in The Feminist Wire. KAY ULUNDAY BARRETTTKay Ulanday Barrett is a published poet, performer, educator, food blogger, cultural worker, and transgender, gender non-conforming, and disability advocate based in New York and New Jersey, whose work has been showcased nationally and internationally. Barrett's writing and performance centers on the experience of queer, transgender, people of color, mixed race people, Asian, and Filipino community. The focus of his artistic work navigates multiple systems of oppression in the context of the U.S. He has also served on committees, organizations, and collectives in attempts to serve communities that desire self-determination. His work and thoughts have been published in media such as Bitch magazine, POOR Magazine, Curve magazine, and PBS News Hour.MAYA REDDYMaya Reddy is a queer South Asian professional golfer and founder of The Gaysian Project—a collective focused on fostering and empowering community through queer Asian visibility. She is a professional ambassador for Athlete Ally, and wrote and extensively researched the implications of queer representation on legislation for her undergraduate thesis. She also spent 3 years working in Hollywood on the development side with the Mark Gordon Company and Night & Day Pictures. Passionate about fighting for queer and female inclusivity in sports as well as raising awareness about Asian and Queer Asian issues. CB LEECB Lee is a bisexual Chinese-Vietnamese American writer whose novels include the Sidekick Squad series, a young adult science fiction adventure that follow queer teens who take on a corrupt government superhero agency, and also the fantasy Seven Tears At High Tide. Lee’s work has been featured in Teen Vogue, Wired Magazine, and Hypable.Not Your Sidekick was a 2017 Lambda Literary Awards Finalist in YA/Children’s Fiction and a 2017 Bisexual Book Awards Finalist in Speculative Fiction. Seven Tears at High Tide was the recipient of a Rainbow Award for Best Bisexual Fantasy Romance and also a finalist for the 2016 Bisexual Book Awards in the YA and Speculative Fiction categories.

story:
Former Riverdancer, Kincaid Stringer has launched a fundraising campaign to lead the charge in supporting the Irish performing arts and entertainment industry from the uncertainties and sheer devastation caused by COVID-19. While many industries were able to continue to function in some capacity during shutdown these pillars within our culture are undoubtedly one of the hardest hit from this global crisis. Ireland is a nation of artists and a land bursting with culture that has brought the world the likes of: Riverdance, Enya, Oscar Wilde, Niall Horan, Pierce Brosnan, Saoirse Ronan, Cillian Murphy, Bono and Liam Neeson. Not to mention the added plethora of talent that has stemmed from the Irish Diaspora thereafter. The list goes on and on, but what it proves is how influential and deeply embedded Irish art and culture are in global society even amongst people who aren’t Irish. In fact, St. Patrick’s Day is the only national holiday that is celebrated throughout the entire world!

My mother, Shannon Kincaid, is a Fine Artist and I, myself, am a former dancer with Riverdance and an entrepreneur who is passionate about Ireland. Together, we have collaborated to create a new series of paintings depicting the various pillars of Irish culture and we are offering prints of them with 100% of the profits going directly to support:

  • Irish musicians, singers and performers
  • Irish dancing schools, clubs and professional dancers
  • Actors, writers and artists
  • Festivals and concerts
  • Theatres and event/cultural spaces
  • Crews & other essential backstage workers

 

All of these various people, groups and institutions have experienced extreme financial hardships after the past several months. Built up rents on studio/rehearsal spaces, cancelled tours and performance runs with no end in sight, pubs and other cultural hubs closed could potentially cripple these industries in a way that they might never recover. It’s also highly likely that funding for upcoming and new projects will suffer. While debunked, it was long rumoured that During WWII Winston Churchill was asked to cut funding for the arts to which he replied, “then what are we fighting for?”  He was quoted, however, saying ““The arts are essential to any complete national life. The State owes it to itself to sus­tain and encour­age them…. Ill fares the race which fails to salute the arts with the rev­er­ence and delight which are their due.” As we fight this current war against the novel coronavirus it feels very fitting to try and use art to help save the entire culture and industry within the arts.

While some would argue that these industries and these areas are nonessential, I would argue the exact opposite. However, I understand the difference between charitable donations to the healthcare system and frontline workers, which is why we are not asking for people’s charity without giving them the option to get something in return. While, there is the option to donate simply out of charity, donations of $25+ will allow people to choose a piece of art that resonates most with them. This collection of art illustrates the greatest parts of Irish culture: music, dance, literature, mythology, festivals and pub culture. We want to make art that celebrates the very best of Irish culture and make accessible to everyone who identifies with it. This is a means of uniting the global Irish community together under a common cause to ensure Irish culture thrives in the times ahead.

Shannon in her studio

 

The Art of Irish Culture Collection:

 

The Dancer:

Irish people’s love of dancing has been well documented throughout their written history. In fact, one of the earliest references to dancing details a visit between the Mayor of Waterford and Mayor of Baltimore in 1413. The modern Irish dancing of today is no longer merely a processional combination of singing and dancing as an act of celebrating, but a sport that produces athletes that are physically strong, as well as creative and artistic. What was once a tradition specific to Ireland (as well as England, Scotland, and some parts of America) caught like wildfire in 1994 with the debut of Riverdance. The theatrical show consisting mainly of traditional Irish music and dance took the world by storm and has been a global phenomenon ever since. Now, twenty-five years later, the Irish dancing community consists of hundreds of thousands, if not millions, of people around the world today. Teachers from around the world have committed themselves to spreading their love and passion for Ireland’s traditional form of expression. Regardless of how far a dancer progresses competitively or professionally, being an Irish dancer is something that is inextricably bound to their identity forevermore. In this piece entitled “The Dancer,” you feel the excitement, the confidence, and the artistry that comes from expressing a centuries-old tradition that has touched the hearts of many.

The Session:

A session is a casual gathering of musicians playing traditional Irish music, usually taking place in a pub, but has also been known to take place on street corners or even in someone’s kitchen. Irish “trad” music has garnered a deep appreciation, not just in Ireland, but also around the world. It’s important to note that a session is more than just a casual jam between musicians – the focus is on the instrumental tunes found within the Irish tradition – reels, jigs, hornpipes, polkas, slip jigs, and the like. Whether it be in a pub or someone’s home, sessions are times of brilliant music and ever-flowing drink that have a certain habit of continuing late into the night, if not into the wee hours of the morning!

 

The Pub:

There is much more to an Irish pub than just having a drink. In Ireland, pubs are central to the way of life. Similar to a church, they represent a pillar of Irish social life and community. A place where pints, comfort food, live music, and sport can be always be found; somewhere you can meet friends, neighbors, or even complete strangers, in an inviting atmosphere. It’s for these reasons that recreations of Irish pubs can be found in any city around the world. O'Connor’s was opened as a pub in Galway in 1942 by Thomas O'Connor, and is currently operated by third generation O’Connors. Every inch of it decorated in eclectic memorabilia, the pub has become famous for its hospitality and world-class live music. So much so that Ed Sheeran used it as the location of his music video “Galway Girl” in 2017 featuring actress Saoirse Ronan, furthering the pub’s world-wide recognition.

 

The Wit:

“Be yourself; everyone else is already taken.”

“To live is the rarest thing in the world. Most people exist, that is all.”

These are just two quotes from one of the biggest literary personalities in Ireland’s history, Oscar Wilde. A literary treasure, Wilde was a hugely popular playwright and poet in the late 1800s. Besides well-known works such as The Picture of Dorian Gray and Lady Windermere’s Fan, his biting wit and flamboyant style gained him notoriety as well. As a people, the Irish are known for their good sense of humour, which has bolstered them during periods of great hardship throughout history. Wilde embodied this intrinsically Irish trait to the very end. Even as he faced death, he was cracking jokes and reportedly said, “This wallpaper and I are fighting a duel to the death. Either it goes or I do.” A collection of art in support of Irish culture would be incomplete without paying homage to Oscar Wilde.

 

The Myth:

Ériu is the goddess of sovereignty and the mythological mother of Ireland. She is often interpreted as the modern-day personification of Ireland. Along with her two sisters, Banba and Fódhla, Ériu was a part of a triumvirate of goddesses. Before their final defeat, each goddess requested that the island be named for her. This was granted to all of them, but Ériu became the chief name in use. The old Irish name Ériu evolved into Éire in modern Irish and depending on the case is spelled Éireann or Éirinn. This is how we finally arrived with the English name for the country, Erin.

The painting has been imbued with symbols to depict all that Ériu embodied within pre-Christian Irish culture. Ériu represents the sacred feminine, as illustrated in the column capitals, or the decorative element at the top of a column, that represent the three phases of a woman’s life cycle – the maid, mother and crone. The stars behind her and the lunala around her neck evoke her role as a lunar goddess. Her hair bleeds into the trees, depicting her connection to the earth and its bounty. She holds this bounty in her hand as a glass of mead, which was served at the feast of Goibhniu, and offered immortality to those that drank it. Around her head is a ring of knot work encasing the land, which is topped by the stone of divisions from the hill of Uisneach, the symbolic and sacred centre of the island in Irish mythology. Ériu’s bones are said to have been laid to rest on this hill and serves as a gateway between the Underworld and the world above.

 

The Rose: 

Ireland has a rich tradition of various festivals taking place throughout each year. The Rose of Tralee was first held in 1959 and has since been held every August in Tralee, County Kerry, to select a young woman to be crowned the Rose. Cities all over the world host their own selection balls to determine who will represent them in Ireland. The festival bills itself as a celebration of the "aspirations, ambitions, intellect, social responsibility, and Irish heritage" of modern young women. Bursting with music and dancing, this festival celebrates the very best of Irish culture and the future of Irish relations worldwide. The winner and their family become a part of a global network, showcasing how Irish culture is thriving amongst the Irish Diaspora. They say, “Once a Rose, always a Rose.”

 

The Gig:

Ireland and Scotland combined have a rich culture within the performing arts, which has resulted in a thriving gig scene. Musicians are constantly pushing the boundaries in order to create new and fresh work that is often steeped in tradition. Many are staunch believers that musical traditions must be preserved as they always have been – the “play it like my father used to” kind of sentimentality. Yet, every generation brings a new wave of talent that feels that this attitude discourages progress and evolution. This debate between tradition and innovation is a tale as old as time. Still, many feel it is possible to honour your origins while also exploring and adapting to the future; they are not mutually exclusive.

Irish music legend, Míchéal Ó Súilleabháinn, believed that traditions are never frozen, but rather are fluid. He believed that the idea of authenticity originating from a pure source located in antiquity was bogus! This painting is for the new wave of artists and musicians who are creating some of the most incredible new-age folk / Trad music in the world. Project Smok, Beoga, Talisk, Ímar and the like are leading the way for the future of Irish music.

“Progress is impossible without change, and those who cannot change their minds cannot change anything.” - George Bernard Shaw

 

Here's the problem:

While established organisations and big business may receive government funding to help overcome these financial challenges, we are interested in providing assistance to the thousands of self-employed individuals, schools, clubs and smaller organisations who teach, perform and share their craft within the performing arts that define our culture.

It's simply a fact that mass gatherings as we were previously accustomed to will be the last thing that will be allowed to resume as normal, meaning that music concerts, album releases, stage productions, dancing competitions, festivals, etc. will most likely feel the effects of COVID-19 longer than any other industry. 

We have all are all currently doing our part by social distancing and self-isolating at home in an effort to get control over the spread of COVID-19. During this chapter of doom and gloom, people are finding joy and welcome escape in all of the creative content that is being uploaded on social media. This has highlighted what a vital role entertainment and the arts, in all of its forms, are to our society and how it is the glue that connects us all to each other. People are using creative expression to bring joy, inspiration and meaning to others. We’ve seen virtual concerts on Zoom, brilliant collaborations with dancers and musicians far and wide and TikTok after TikTok and hilarious memes that we’ll never forget. It’s true that the arts create hope and healing.


Yet, as restrictions ease and we begin rebuilding essential businesses and local economies, there will be significant cuts in areas that are deemed nonessential. Potentially, what will have been a very large part of what helped us endure this pandemic will suffer. We must ensure that performing artists (actors, dancers, musicians, singers, theatres and leaders within artistic disciplines) do not just survive, but thrive after we emerge from this!
 

Here’s our solution:

Our culture is what unites us. It’s the glue that binds us altogether regardless where in the world we may be. It’s the music, the dance, the song, the wit and written word and the craic. Ireland may be a small island but more than 80 million people around the world call her home. There are roughly 30 million Irish Americans in the States, while the total population of Ireland is just 6.2 million. The Irish global population is a tight knit one that stretches across nearly every country on the planet. I have always said that if the world is six degrees of separation, Ireland is two and Irish dancing is one. If you know one person, you know them all.

Imagine if we were able to get donations from just 1% of that population. What unbelievable relief could we provide to the people who help define our own identity as being Irish? That is why we’re seeking donations to support everything that it means to be Irish and calling upon anyone who identifies or has every enjoyed the fruits of Irish culture. There’s a saying in Irish, “ní neart go cur le chéile,” which means “There is no strength without unity.” And now is the time, more than ever, to unite as one people and band together.

Once we have achieved our fundraising goal we will begin accepting applications and start distribute the money directly to anyone within the Irish performing arts or any cultural endeavours in need of financial support.

This fundraising campaign is intended to help alleviate this newfound reality so many have found themselves in. Even though you can’t go to a show or a concert to see or hear anyone perform, but you can still support them. This new collection of paintings is available to anyone and everyone who feels a connection to Ireland and her culture.

We have intentionally priced the prints at roughly the cost of a typical social gathering / interaction, for example:

  1. What’s the average price of a ticket to a: shows, concerts or gigs you were unable to attend because of COVID-19?
  2. What’s the average price to enter a dancing competition?
  3. On average what would you spend on a round of drinks?
  4. What’s the average price of admission into a lecture or seminar?

International travel is surely to be heavily restricted for the foreseeable future so if you love Ireland and identity with the culture, but maybe can’t visit or return anytime soon we would ask that you consider buying a print to support this cause.

Let’s use these prints as a reminder of the times we have endured and the things we have sacrificed and hopefully these paintings will be a reminder of the things that we truly value as a people and a culture.

 

Technical Information:

All of the artwork has been professionally scanned at one of the leading Fine Art reproduction firms in the United States called Coupralux. Together we have designed the layout of each print and approved the samples. We are just waiting to place the official order with our printer once the campaign is completed!

Sizes are as follows: 

  • The Dancer: 12”x10”
  • The Session: 10”x14”
  • The Pub: 9”x12”
  • The Wit: 12”x10”
  • The Myth: 14”x10”
  • The Rose: 14”x8”
  • The Gig: 12”x12”

- Each Print is finished with a 1" border

- Paper: Art Print Quality with a Matte Finish

As these are slightly unusual sizes we recommend floating frames should you decide to frame the prints. They are extremely affordable and come in nearly any style you can imagine!

 

A little more about Shannon and Kincaid:

Shannon is a versatile fine artist whose portfolio includes paintings of Oprah Winfrey, James Bond Girl, Luciana Paluzzi, Mickey Mantle and The Dallas Cowboy’s legendary coach, Tom Landry. She is also one of the leading and finest portrait artists in the world with an extensive clientele. Shannon has also had a career as a singer, having recorded several albums. Her first, in 2005, was a Grammy contender, being nominated in three categories: best album, best song and best female vocalist, where Shannon’s name was beneath Alicia Keys'. 

This isn’t the first time Shannon has used her artwork to raise awareness for charitable and noble causes. After the horrific terrorist attack of September 11, 2001, Shannon painted two life-sized paintings of a policeman and a fireman and called them The New Twin Towers. The paintings were sent to New York City, where they resided in the front windows of Ground Zero’s popular restaurant, Gino’s, alerting the first responders where they could come and eat for free. Because of their high visibility and historical significance, the paintings were acquired by the New York Historical Society and the Fireman’s Museum.

In 2006, Shannon received word that she’d won the Lilly Oncology International Art Contest for her painting “Will He Still Love Me?” out of 2000 entries from 43 countries. Her painting traveled to the Royal Academy of London for a week’s exhibition and from there, toured the world for the next two years, raising money for the cause of breast cancer.

In 2007, Shannon painted the cover of a book titled TORCH, written by survivors of ovarian cancer. It was the authors’ hope to be invited onto the Oprah show to discuss ovarian cancer, which gets much less press than other cancers. When months of trying proved fruitless, Shannon had the idea of painting Oprah, herself, in a way that portrayed her humanitarian spirit, by depicting her with one of the children from her leadership academy in Johannesburg, South Africa. Included in the crate with the painting was the TORCH book and all the local press it had received. It surely got their attention and when Oprah came to open the Texas State Fair that fall, she and Shannon got to meet and discuss the TORCH ladies and their project. Oprah promised to have a show discussing ovarian cancer as soon as it was possible. She was true to her word and the following summer, there were two shows devoted to the subject by her successor, Dr. Oz. Oprah had her portrait shipped to the school in South Africa, where it hangs above the mantle in the library and is said to be the students’ favorite piece of art on the entire campus. 

 

Kincaid Stringer is a former dancer with Riverdance, entrepreneur and currently teaches with The Hession School of Irish Dancing in Galway, Ireland. In 2011 he was featured on the cover of the Irish Dance Magazine as the first "Man of The Year." He has performed all over the world and is proud to share his love for Irish culture where ever he goes.  He has also an active member of the Ireland Fund's Young Leaders programme for the past six years which is a global fundraising network for people of Irish ancestry and friends of Ireland, dedicated to raising funds to support programs of peace and reconciliation, arts and culture, education and community development throughout the island of Ireland. 

Kincaid enlisted the help of his mother to create a collection of paintings that would fully manifest the idea of Irish art supporting the Irish arts. Together, they hope that the pieces resonate with others and bring the Irish community around the world a sense of togetherness during a time when we all had to remain apart. 

"I hope to embolden and motivate the millions of Irish people around the world to take action and ensure that our people and our culture don’t survive, but thrive."

Kincaid pictured here with several of his pupils at The Hession ball celebrating their successes at the Irish Dancing World Championships in 2019. The 2020 World Championships were, unfortunately, canceled due to COVID-19

 

About Shipping:

  • Shipping is available worldwide.
  • The cost of shipping is applied at check out.
  • Shipping rates may vary depending upon country of origin.

 

Why IndieGoGo?

Other fundraising platforms like GoFundMe are great options when raising money for causes and other charities. We realised that the arts and culture didn’t fall within the immediate need for relief like that of frontline and healthcare providers, which is why we’ve chosen to use IndieGoGo so that we may offer backers various options to get something in return for supporting our cause. Together, we believe that we can unite the Irish Diaspora in support and celebration of our shared culture.

Every little bit helps so even if you’re not in a place to contribute to our campaign right now, your voice is still valuable! Please take the time to share us on your various social media accounts and help spread the word amongst all of your friends!

 

Risks and Challenges:

While, we have set our fundraising goal at $250,000 we believe there is the potential to raise much more, which will all be dedicated to supporting the Irish arts and culture. It’s a win-win for everyone. People who love Ireland not only get a piece of Fine Art that illustrates the various aspects of our culture, but they also get the satisfaction of knowing that they were able to contribute to a fund that will help preserve and grow Irish culture going forward.

The great challenge we foresee is getting the campaign in front of as many people as possible. Our initial fundraising goal requires at that we have 10,000 people back the campaign provided they purchase one print. But, there are millions of Irish people around the world who we are confident this project will resonate with so we just have to work hard enough to ensure that they hear about what we’re doing.

If for any reason you have questions or concerns, please feel free to email us at:

irishartsandculturefund@gmail.com and we will get back to as soon as possible! 

We thank you for your consideration.

- Kincaid & Shannon

In Ireland, pubs are central to the way of life. Similar to a church, they represent a pillar of Irish social life and community. A place where pints, comfort food, live music, and sport can be always be found; somewhere you can meet friends, neighbors, or even complete strangers, in an inviting atmosphere. It’s for these reasons that recreations of Irish pubs can be found in any city around the world. O'Connor’s was opened as a pub in Galway in 1942 by Thomas O'Connor, and is currently operated by third generation O’Connors. Every inch of it decorated in eclectic memorabilia, the pub has become famous for its hospitality and world-class live music. So much so that Ed Sheeran used it as the location of his music video “Galway Girl” in 2017 featuring actress Saoirse Ronan, furthering the pub’s world-wide recognition. The Wit:“Be yourself; everyone else is already taken.” “To live is the rarest thing in the world. Most people exist, that is all.”These are just two quotes from one of the biggest literary personalities in Ireland’s history, Oscar Wilde. A literary treasure, Wilde was a hugely popular playwright and poet in the late 1800s. Besides well-known works such as The Picture of Dorian Gray and Lady Windermere’s Fan, his biting wit and flamboyant style gained him notoriety as well. As a people, the Irish are known for their good sense of humour, which has bolstered them during periods of great hardship throughout history. Wilde embodied this intrinsically Irish trait to the very end. Even as he faced death, he was cracking jokes and reportedly said, “This wallpaper and I are fighting a duel to the death. Either it goes or I do.” A collection of art in support of Irish culture would be incomplete without paying homage to Oscar Wilde. The Myth:Ériu is the goddess of sovereignty and the mythological mother of Ireland. She is often interpreted as the modern-day personification of Ireland. Along with her two sisters, Banba and Fódhla, Ériu was a part of a triumvirate of goddesses. Before their final defeat, each goddess requested that the island be named for her. This was granted to all of them, but Ériu became the chief name in use. The old Irish name Ériu evolved into Éire in modern Irish and depending on the case is spelled Éireann or Éirinn. This is how we finally arrived with the English name for the country, Erin.The painting has been imbued with symbols to depict all that Ériu embodied within pre-Christian Irish culture. Ériu represents the sacred feminine, as illustrated in the column capitals, or the decorative element at the top of a column, that represent the three phases of a woman’s life cycle – the maid, mother and crone. The stars behind her and the lunala around her neck evoke her role as a lunar goddess. Her hair bleeds into the trees, depicting her connection to the earth and its bounty. She holds this bounty in her hand as a glass of mead, which was served at the feast of Goibhniu, and offered immortality to those that drank it. Around her head is a ring of knot work encasing the land, which is topped by the stone of divisions from the hill of Uisneach, the symbolic and sacred centre of the island in Irish mythology. Ériu’s bones are said to have been laid to rest on this hill and serves as a gateway between the Underworld and the world above. The Rose: Ireland has a rich tradition of various festivals taking place throughout each year. The Rose of Tralee was first held in 1959 and has since been held every August in Tralee, County Kerry, to select a young woman to be crowned the Rose. Cities all over the world host their own selection balls to determine who will represent them in Ireland. The festival bills itself as a celebration of the "aspirations, ambitions, intellect, social responsibility, and Irish heritage" of modern young women. Bursting with music and dancing, this festival celebrates the very best of Irish culture and the future of Irish relations worldwide. The winner and their family become a part of a global network, showcasing how Irish culture is thriving amongst the Irish Diaspora. They say, “Once a Rose, always a Rose.” The Gig:Ireland and Scotland combined have a rich culture within the performing arts, which has resulted in a thriving gig scene. Musicians are constantly pushing the boundaries in order to create new and fresh work that is often steeped in tradition. Many are staunch believers that musical traditions must be preserved as they always have been – the “play it like my father used to” kind of sentimentality. Yet, every generation brings a new wave of talent that feels that this attitude discourages progress and evolution. This debate between tradition and innovation is a tale as old as time. Still, many feel it is possible to honour your origins while also exploring and adapting to the future; they are not mutually exclusive.Irish music legend, Míchéal Ó Súilleabháinn, believed that traditions are never frozen, but rather are fluid. He believed that the idea of authenticity originating from a pure source located in antiquity was bogus! This painting is for the new wave of artists and musicians who are creating some of the most incredible new-age folk / Trad music in the world. Project Smok, Beoga, Talisk, Ímar and the like are leading the way for the future of Irish music.“Progress is impossible without change, and those who cannot change their minds cannot change anything.” - George Bernard Shaw Here's the problem:While established organisations and big business may receive government funding to help overcome these financial challenges, we are interested in providing assistance to the thousands of self-employed individuals, schools, clubs and smaller organisations who teach, perform and share their craft within the performing arts that define our culture.It's simply a fact that mass gatherings as we were previously accustomed to will be the last thing that will be allowed to resume as normal, meaning that music concerts, album releases, stage productions, dancing competitions, festivals, etc. will most likely feel the effects of COVID-19 longer than any other industry. We have all are all currently doing our part by social distancing and self-isolating at home in an effort to get control over the spread of COVID-19. During this chapter of doom and gloom, people are finding joy and welcome escape in all of the creative content that is being uploaded on social media. This has highlighted what a vital role entertainment and the arts, in all of its forms, are to our society and how it is the glue that connects us all to each other. People are using creative expression to bring joy, inspiration and meaning to others. We’ve seen virtual concerts on Zoom, brilliant collaborations with dancers and musicians far and wide and TikTok after TikTok and hilarious memes that we’ll never forget. It’s true that the arts create hope and healing.Yet, as restrictions ease and we begin rebuilding essential businesses and local economies, there will be significant cuts in areas that are deemed nonessential. Potentially, what will have been a very large part of what helped us endure this pandemic will suffer. We must ensure that performing artists (actors, dancers, musicians, singers, theatres and leaders within artistic disciplines) do not just survive, but thrive after we emerge from this! Here’s our solution:Our culture is what unites us. It’s the glue that binds us altogether regardless where in the world we may be. It’s the music, the dance, the song, the wit and written word and the craic. Ireland may be a small island but more than 80 million people around the world call her home. There are roughly 30 million Irish Americans in the States, while the total population of Ireland is just 6.2 million. The Irish global population is a tight knit one that stretches across nearly every country on the planet. I have always said that if the world is six degrees of separation, Ireland is two and Irish dancing is one. If you know one person, you know them all.Imagine if we were able to get donations from just 1% of that population. What unbelievable relief could we provide to the people who help define our own identity as being Irish? That is why we’re seeking donations to support everything that it means to be Irish and calling upon anyone who identifies or has every enjoyed the fruits of Irish culture. There’s a saying in Irish, “ní neart go cur le chéile,” which means “There is no strength without unity.” And now is the time, more than ever, to unite as one people and band together.Once we have achieved our fundraising goal we will begin accepting applications and start distribute the money directly to anyone within the Irish performing arts or any cultural endeavours in need of financial support.This fundraising campaign is intended to help alleviate this newfound reality so many have found themselves in. Even though you can’t go to a show or a concert to see or hear anyone perform, but you can still support them. This new collection of paintings is available to anyone and everyone who feels a connection to Ireland and her culture.We have intentionally priced the prints at roughly the cost of a typical social gathering / interaction, for example:
What’s the average price of a ticket to a: shows, concerts or gigs you were unable to attend because of COVID-19?
What’s the average price to enter a dancing competition?
On average what would you spend on a round of drinks?
What’s the average price of admission into a lecture or seminar?
International travel is surely to be heavily restricted for the foreseeable future so if you love Ireland and identity with the culture, but maybe can’t visit or return anytime soon we would ask that you consider buying a print to support this cause.Let’s use these prints as a reminder of the times we have endured and the things we have sacrificed and hopefully these paintings will be a reminder of the things that we truly value as a people and a culture. Technical Information:All of the artwork has been professionally scanned at one of the leading Fine Art reproduction firms in the United States called Coupralux. Together we have designed the layout of each print and approved the samples. We are just waiting to place the official order with our printer once the campaign is completed!Sizes are as follows: 
The Dancer: 12”x10”
The Session: 10”x14”
The Pub: 9”x12”
The Wit: 12”x10”
The Myth: 14”x10”
The Rose: 14”x8”
The Gig: 12”x12”
- Each Print is finished with a 1" border- Paper: Art Print Quality with a Matte FinishAs these are slightly unusual sizes we recommend floating frames should you decide to frame the prints. They are extremely affordable and come in nearly any style you can imagine! A little more about Shannon and Kincaid:Shannon is a versatile fine artist whose portfolio includes paintings of Oprah Winfrey, James Bond Girl, Luciana Paluzzi, Mickey Mantle and The Dallas Cowboy’s legendary coach, Tom Landry. She is also one of the leading and finest portrait artists in the world with an extensive clientele. Shannon has also had a career as a singer, having recorded several albums. Her first, in 2005, was a Grammy contender, being nominated in three categories: best album, best song and best female vocalist, where Shannon’s name was beneath Alicia Keys'. This isn’t the first time Shannon has used her artwork to raise awareness for charitable and noble causes. After the horrific terrorist attack of September 11, 2001, Shannon painted two life-sized paintings of a policeman and a fireman and called them The New Twin Towers. The paintings were sent to New York City, where they resided in the front windows of Ground Zero’s popular restaurant, Gino’s, alerting the first responders where they could come and eat for free. Because of their high visibility and historical significance, the paintings were acquired by the New York Historical Society and the Fireman’s Museum.In 2006, Shannon received word that she’d won the Lilly Oncology International Art Contest for her painting “Will He Still Love Me?” out of 2000 entries from 43 countries. Her painting traveled to the Royal Academy of London for a week’s exhibition and from there, toured the world for the next two years, raising money for the cause of breast cancer.In 2007, Shannon painted the cover of a book titled TORCH, written by survivors of ovarian cancer. It was the authors’ hope to be invited onto the Oprah show to discuss ovarian cancer, which gets much less press than other cancers. When months of trying proved fruitless, Shannon had the idea of painting Oprah, herself, in a way that portrayed her humanitarian spirit, by depicting her with one of the children from her leadership academy in Johannesburg, South Africa. Included in the crate with the painting was the TORCH book and all the local press it had received. It surely got their attention and when Oprah came to open the Texas State Fair that fall, she and Shannon got to meet and discuss the TORCH ladies and their project. Oprah promised to have a show discussing ovarian cancer as soon as it was possible. She was true to her word and the following summer, there were two shows devoted to the subject by her successor, Dr. Oz. Oprah had her portrait shipped to the school in South Africa, where it hangs above the mantle in the library and is said to be the students’ favorite piece of art on the entire campus.  Kincaid Stringer is a former dancer with Riverdance, entrepreneur and currently teaches with The Hession School of Irish Dancing in Galway, Ireland. In 2011 he was featured on the cover of the Irish Dance Magazine as the first "Man of The Year." He has performed all over the world and is proud to share his love for Irish culture where ever he goes.  He has also an active member of the Ireland Fund's Young Leaders programme for the past six years which is a global fundraising network for people of Irish ancestry and friends of Ireland, dedicated to raising funds to support programs of peace and reconciliation, arts and culture, education and community development throughout the island of Ireland. Kincaid enlisted the help of his mother to create a collection of paintings that would fully manifest the idea of Irish art supporting the Irish arts. Together, they hope that the pieces resonate with others and bring the Irish community around the world a sense of togetherness during a time when we all had to remain apart. "I hope to embolden and motivate the millions of Irish people around the world to take action and ensure that our people and our culture don’t survive, but thrive."Kincaid pictured here with several of his pupils at The Hession ball celebrating their successes at the Irish Dancing World Championships in 2019. The 2020 World Championships were, unfortunately, canceled due to COVID-19 About Shipping:
Shipping is available worldwide.
The cost of shipping is applied at check out.
Shipping rates may vary depending upon country of origin.
 Why IndieGoGo?Other fundraising platforms like GoFundMe are great options when raising money for causes and other charities. We realised that the arts and culture didn’t fall within the immediate need for relief like that of frontline and healthcare providers, which is why we’ve chosen to use IndieGoGo so that we may offer backers various options to get something in return for supporting our cause. Together, we believe that we can unite the Irish Diaspora in support and celebration of our shared culture.Every little bit helps so even if you’re not in a place to contribute to our campaign right now, your voice is still valuable! Please take the time to share us on your various social media accounts and help spread the word amongst all of your friends! Risks and Challenges:While, we have set our fundraising goal at $250,000 we believe there is the potential to raise much more, which will all be dedicated to supporting the Irish arts and culture. It’s a win-win for everyone. People who love Ireland not only get a piece of Fine Art that illustrates the various aspects of our culture, but they also get the satisfaction of knowing that they were able to contribute to a fund that will help preserve and grow Irish culture going forward.The great challenge we foresee is getting the campaign in front of as many people as possible. Our initial fundraising goal requires at that we have 10,000 people back the campaign provided they purchase one print. But, there are millions of Irish people around the world who we are confident this project will resonate with so we just have to work hard enough to ensure that they hear about what we’re doing.If for any reason you have questions or concerns, please feel free to email us at:irishartsandculturefund@gmail.com and we will get back to as soon as possible! We thank you for your consideration.- Kincaid & Shannon

story:
CHOLA CONTRAVISUAL

Somos comunicadoras  feministas que buscamos alcanzar colectivamente existencias felices, libres y plenas para las mujeres y las personas LGTBIQ. Narramos desde experiencias compartidas y propias, una alternativa al discurso dominante, visibilizando e impulsando rebeldías que desafían las opresiones y los órdenes establecidos.  Nuestro núcleo de trabajo son la comunicación, la formación libre y la gestión cultural.

 

LA MUNAY

Munay es una palabra en quechua; es un principio que nos habla de la voluntad del amor y del amor recíproco como eje principal de la vida, algo tan sencillo como caminar juntxs en la misma dirección, aún si somos diferentes en cuerpo y mente.

Hace ya siete meses abrimos nuestra casa junto a diversas compañeras feministas de la ciudad de Huancayo por que en nuestros corazones sabemos que hay otra salida y otro mundo posible. Un mundo donde tengamos cabida quienes escapamos de la norma, quienes no encajamos en su moral y que cuestionamos el orden patriarcal. La diversidad es incompatible con un sistema empeñado en negar la posibilidad de la existencia de otras identidades, otros cuerpos y otras formas de vivir y experimentar la sexualidad y el género. En el mundo al que aspiramos la diversidad es la base para una democracia real, inclusiva, igualitaria y justa.

Soñamos que el feminismo invada todos los espacios en los que somos socializadas para que su capacidad transformadora y revolucionaria nos permita encontrarnos con otras, otros y otres. Hablamos de un espacio para todes, abierto a nuestros sentires y pensares generando místicas colectivas más solidarias, participativas y  procesos comunitarios entre cómplices que activen profundas transformaciones micropolíticas, redes de afecto y creatividad, acción colectiva contra las opresiones a favor de la libertad y al derecho a renunciar a las formas de vida impuestas, la autonomía, la visibilidad, la felicidad de las mujeres y las personas disidentes de la sexualidad y el género.

La Munay es sinónimo de ilusión y fuerza, un espacio lleno de aprendizajes para entender de dónde venimos y continuar construyendo respuestas feministas colectivas contra el machismo. Una tarea cada vez más complicada en una ciudad como Huancayo 

Desde la apertura de La Munay, venimos realizando diversas actividades, talleres, encuentros, conversatorios,  biblioteca ambulante, eventos artísticos, etc.

¿POR QUE LO HACEMOS?

El feminismo no es sólo una lucha más que sumar, es un pilar central de la sociedad que aspiramos a construir. Lo es como herramienta de auto-organización, de empoderamiento, de elaboración política, para las mujeres que encontramos en el movimiento feminista un espacio desde el que ser protagonistas de nuestra lucha. Y lo es como movimiento que pone patas arriba el sistema, al poner en cuestión cuál debe ser la lógica que mueva el mundo. El feminismo trata de visibilizar lo invisible, de dar voz a quien no la tiene y de politizar lo cotidiano.

 

El PROBLEMA

Durante estos siete meses de existencia La Munay ha venido trabajando desde la economía solidaria y la autogestión, nos unimos para hacerle frente a las lógicas capitalistas de consumo y producción en un mundo patriarcal y hostil para las mujeres y personas LGTBIQ, en donde el encontrarse es una necesidad  en épocas de crisis que nos pegan siempre más duro a nosotrxs.

Les somos honestas, no ha sido sencillo.

 El individualismo ha dificultando que nos relacionemos a partir de lo que necesitamos conjuntamente y día a día se confabula para que espacios como el nuestro no abran más.

 

QUE HAREMOS CON TU AYUDA

Con tu aporte buscamos seguir manteniendo abierta LA MUNAY y que siga ofreciendo un espacio inclusivo, un espacio liberado  de actitudes opresoras, donde fortalecernos, cuidarnos y hacer que la lucha feminista se visibilice, multiplique y propague. 

A la vez también queremos ampliar los servicios que ofrecemos a las mujeres, poder gestionar más actividades y implementar una biblioteca, una sala de proyección, entre otras cosas. 

¡Ayúdanos a seguir tejiendo nuestros sueños y esperanzas!

 

Además:

¿Cómo donar si no tienes tarjeta de crédito o débito? (Sólo Perú)�
1.- Escoge la cantidad y el premio que más te guste (o deposita la cantidad que tú quieras)
2.- Ve al BCP más cercano y deposita la cantidad que desees en la cuenta de ahorros 191-34897502-0-00
3.- Escanea o toma foto a tu recibo y envíalo a munayfeminista@gmail.com con tu nombre y primer apellido, así podremos rastrear fácilmente tu depósito y enviarte la recompensa.

 

*************************************************************************************

ABOUT "CHOLA CONTRAVISUAL"

We are feminist communicators who look for achieve collectively a happy, free and full existences for women and LGTBIQ people. We narrate from shared and own experiences, an alternative to the dominant discourse, visibilizing and promoting rebellions that defy oppressions and established orders. Our core work are communication, free training and cultural management.

 

ABOUT "LA MUNAY"

Munay is a quechua word; is a principle that tells us about the will of love and reciprocal love as the main axis of life, something as simple as walking together in the same direction, even if we are different in body and mind.

Seven months ago we opened our house with the help of several feminist partners from Huancayo city, because in our hearts we know that there is another way out and another possible world. A world where fit those who has escaped from the norm, those who do not fit in their moral and who question the patriarchal order. Diversity is incompatible with a system bent on denying the possibility of the existence of other identities, other bodies and other ways of living and experiment sexuality and gender. In the world we aspire, diversity is the base for a real, inclusive, egalitarian and just democracy.

We dream that feminism invades all the spaces in which we are socialized and with its transformative and revolutionary capacity allows us to meet others. We speak about a space for all, open to our feelings and thinkings, generating a mystical collective more solidarity, participatory and community processes between accomplices that generate deep micropolitical transformations, networks of affection and creativity, collective actions against oppression in favor of freedom and the right to renounce to imposed forms of life, autonomy, visibility, happiness of women and dissidents of sexuality and gender.

La Munay is synonymous for strength and illusion, a filled space of apprenticeship to understand where we come from and continue building a collective feminist responses against machism. An increasingly complicated task in a city like Huancayo

Since the opening of La Munay, we have been carrying out several activities, workshops, meetings, talks, traveling library, art events, etc.

 

WHY DO WE DO IT?

Feminism is not just a struggle to add, it is a central pillar of society that we aspire to build. It is a tool for self-organization, empowerment, and political development, for women who find in the feminist movement a space from which to be protagonists of our struggle. And it is as a movement that puts the system upside down, by calling into question what the logic that moves the world should be. Feminism tries to make visible the invisible, to give voice to those who do not have it and to politicize the everyday.

 

THE PROBLEM

During these seven months of existence La Munay has been working from the solidarity economy and self-management, we unite to face the capitalist logics of consumption and production in a patriarchal and hostile world for women and LGTBIQ people, where is a necessity meet us in times of crisis that always hit us harder.

If we are honest, it has not been easy.

Individualism has made it difficult for us to relate from what we need as group and day by day is conspiring for spaces like ours do not open anymore.

 

WHAT WE WILL DO WITH YOUR HELP

With your contribution, we look for to continue to keep open LA MUNAY and continue to offering an inclusive space, a space liberated from oppressive attitudes, where we can strengthen and take care of ourselves and make the feminist struggle become visible, multiply and propagate.

At the same time we also want to expand the services we offer to women, to be able to manage more activities and to implement a library, a projection room, among other things.

Help us to continue weaving our dreams and hopes!

It is a tool for self-organization, empowerment, and political development, for women who find in the feminist movement a space from which to be protagonists of our struggle. And it is as a movement that puts the system upside down, by calling into question what the logic that moves the world should be. Feminism tries to make visible the invisible, to give voice to those who do not have it and to politicize the everyday. THE PROBLEMDuring these seven months of existence La Munay has been working from the solidarity economy and self-management, we unite to face the capitalist logics of consumption and production in a patriarchal and hostile world for women and LGTBIQ people, where is a necessity meet us in times of crisis that always hit us harder.If we are honest, it has not been easy.Individualism has made it difficult for us to relate from what we need as group and day by day is conspiring for spaces like ours do not open anymore. WHAT WE WILL DO WITH YOUR HELPWith your contribution, we look for to continue to keep open LA MUNAY and continue to offering an inclusive space, a space liberated from oppressive attitudes, where we can strengthen and take care of ourselves and make the feminist struggle become visible, multiply and propagate.At the same time we also want to expand the services we offer to women, to be able to manage more activities and to implement a library, a projection room, among other things.Help us to continue weaving our dreams and hopes!

story:
FESTIVAL INTERNATIONAL DE CAPOEIRA AU BENIN

- INTERNATIONAL CAPOEIRA FESTIVAL IN BENIN

 L’Association Capoeira Bénin vous invite à soutenir le troisième festival international de Capoeira au Bénin, qui aura lieu du 23 au 28 Mai 2017. Ce festival vise à reconnaître la culture afro-brésilienne au Bénin et en Afrique de l’Ouest.

 

– The Association Capoeira Bénin invites you to support the third international Capoeira festival in Benin, which will take place May 23-28 2017. This festival aims to recognize afro-Brazilian culture in Benin and West Africa.

Bonjour à tous ! L’Association Capoeira Bénin (A.C.B.) a le plaisir de vous présenter ce projet de Festival International de Capoeira au Bénin ! Chaque jour, nous découvrons un peu plus l’histoire afro-brésilienne qui est ancrée dans notre patrimoine, par exemple dans l’architecture (villes de Porto Novo, Agoué, Ouidah), dans les dialectes (dans les mots Tchavi - Clé, Igredja-église, Akara-beignet de beurre), et dans notre culture (en cuisine, danse, cérémonies, et capoeira !)… Le festival que nous organisons est une occasion de partager ces découvertes avec vous.

– Hello everybody! The Association Capoeira Benin (A.C.B.) is happy to present you this project of International Capoeira Festival in Benin! Every day, we discover a little bit more on afro-Brazilian history, which is represented in an architectural, linguistic and cultural heritage here in Benin. This festival is an opportunity to share about this heritage, and acknowledge the African influence in Brazilian culture.

 

La Capoeira au Bénin – Capoeira in Benin

La capoeira est un art de combat et danse afro-brésilien originaire des pratiques des peuples africains du temps de l'esclavage au Brésil. La capoeira consiste en un jeu entre deux personnes qui se pratique dans un espace circulaire (la roda) formé par un nombre indéfini de personnes qui chantent en rythme. La Capoeira est reconnue comme patrimoine culturel immatériel de l'humanité (UNESCO, 2014). Elle représente une activité culturelle, d’éducation physique et sportive, et permet de développer la discipline, sociabilité, sensibilité, coordination, musique et l’autonomie, à tous les âges, genres, races et religions.

La pratique de la capoeira au Bénin est relativement récente : le premier et le seul groupe de Capoeira au Bénin, Ogun Eru (Capoeira, lutte et héritage des Africains contraints à l'esclavage) a commencé en 2003 sous l’initiative de Mamoudou FASSASSI. Plus d'une centaine d'étudiants font maintenant partie du groupe ! L'Association Capoeira Bénin (A.C.B.), créée en 2013, soutient le groupe à promouvoir la capoeira au Bénin, en Afrique de l'Ouest et dans le reste du monde.

– Capoeira is an Afro-Brazilian martial art and dance originating from practices from African communities in the time of slavery in Brazil. It consists of a two-player game practiced in a circular space (the Roda), formed by other people playing music and singing in rhythm. In 2014, Capoeira was inscribed on the UNESCO Representative List of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity. Capoeira represents an excellent cultural, physical and educational activity which teaches discipline and sociability, stimulates sensibility, and helps develop motor skills.

 

The practice of Capoeira in Benin is very recent, as the first and only Capoeira group in Benin, Ogun Eru (Capoeira, fight and heritage of Africans forced to slavery), started in 2003. More than one hundred students are now part of the group and Capoeira has demonstrated its capacity to promote social and cultural development in Benin on multiple levels. The non-profit organization A.C.B was created in 2013, to support the group and promote Capoeira in Benin, West Africa and the rest of the world.

 

Quel est le but de ce festival ? – What is the objective of this festival ?

Le festival aura lieu du 23 au 28 mai et inclura des ateliers de Capoeira pour tous les âges, des démonstrations de Capoeira, des visites touristiques et des conférences. Le caractère unique de cet événement est la cérémonie de Formatura du Mestre Fassassi: pour une première fois en Afrique, un africain va recevoir le titre de maître de capoeira. Le festival sera une merveilleuse occasion de rassembler des groupes de capoeira du monde entier, en particulier d'Afrique de l'Ouest et du Brésil.

 

– The 2017 International Capoeira Festival will take place on May 23-28, 2017, and will include Capoeira workshops for all ages, capoeira demonstrations, touristic visits and conferences. The unique character of this event is the Formatura (graduation) ceremony of Mestre Fassassi: for the first time in Africa, an African will receive the international title of capoeira Mestre (master). The International Capoeira Festival will also represent a great opportunity to bring groups of capoeira from around the world, especially West Africa and Brazil, together.

De quoi avons-nous besoin ? – What do we need ?

Nous travaillons en étroite collaboration avec l'ambassade du Brésil ainsi que des écoles internationales au Bénin, mais nous avons besoin d'un soutien supplémentaire pour voir le festival se réaliser. Cette collecte de fonds vise à rassembler le montant nécessaire pour couvrir : les frais d’organisation, les couts de transport, les locations de salles, l’hébergement des invités, l’achat de quelques instruments de Capoeira et le reportage télévisé de l’évènement.

Pour nous aider à faire en sorte que cet évènement se réalise, vous pouvez :

- Faire une donation

- Partager cette page

- Suivre notre groupe sur Facebook : CM Fassassi (Capoeira Ogun Eru)

- Suivre et partager l’évènement sur Facebook : Festival International Capoeira Benin

Vous êtes bien sûr les bienvenus au Bénin, au festival, et à nos entrainements ! Merci!

 

– We work in close collaboration with the Brazilian Embassy and international schools in Benin, but we need additional help to ensure the realization of this event. This fundraising aims collecting the necessary amount of money to cover : organisational costs, transport, rental of the venue, Brazilian music instruments and video recording of the event.

To help us make this festival happen :

- Donate

- Share this page

- Follow the group on Facebook : CM Fassassi (Capoeira Ogun Eru)

- Like the event on Facebook : Festival International Capoeira Benin

You are welcome in Benin, at the festival, and at our weekly trainings ! Thank you !

 

Contact :

Association Capoeira Benin (A.C.B.)

(+299) 95790443/97034410

capoeirabenin@gmail.com

https://web.facebook.com/mamoudou.fassassi

story:
As the ISIS occupation of Iraq and Syria wanes, Music and Dance provide a positive focus to aspiring youth gathering from across the Middle East in Iraq and Lebanon. 

The YES Academy Youth Orchestra performs in Beirut, Lebanon

On July 14, six musicians from recently liberated Mosul will undertake a short, but arduous 50-mile journey into the Iraqi Region of Kurdistan. Recently freed from the harsh rule of ISIS, they will be welcomed by the Youth Excellence on Stage (YES) Academy Erbil, an oasis of learning and collaboration that will give them the freedom to play and create in peace with other young performing artists from across Iraq. 

Later in the month, a group of 30 courageous young Syrian musicians will depart for Lebanon. Though only 80 miles, their journey will be comprised of security checkpoints, passport controls and unpredictable inspections, arriving at YES Academy Lebanon.

 

String players rehearse at the YES Academy in Erbil, Iraq

Since 2007 American Voices has worked in Lebanon and Iraq to create safe and nurturing environments for thousands of young performing artists. In this environment youth come together and study music and dance with professional teaching artists from the United States.  In July, we will return to Erbil, Iraq to offer a nation-wide program in orchestra, guitar, voice, composition, and hip hop dance to over 150 students.  We will also return to Lebanon in August to offer a region-wide program encompassing orchestra, piano, guitar, voice, composition, and entrepreneurship to students from Lebanon, Syria, Jordan and Egypt.

 

Breakdance students perform at a U.N. refugee camp in Erbil

In celebration of these ten years of academies, we will expand our program opening our doors to include youth from the recently freed Mosul and Ninevah region as well as from Baghdad, Kirkuk, and across Kurdistan.  

Your support will impact the lives of 300 youth. For these youth our academies are the only time of the year to hone their skills in programs ranging from orchestra and composition to hip hop dance. Our academies provide the only opportunities for both children and young adults from across the region to play in a youth orchestra, write new music, sing opera, dance, and play in guitar orchestra.

Your generous gift will allow us to:

  • Host two YES Academies in Iraq and Lebanon, reaching over 300 youth from Iraq, Lebanon, Syria, Jordan and Egypt.
  • Train six participants from Mosul, young musicians only recently liberated from the ISIS occupation, as they form a new band coached by American Voices faculty.
  • Provide six YES Academy alumni an opportunity to return as student leaders, assisting with program administration while receiving entrepreneurship, teaching and management training.
  • Welcome two new scholarship students from Iraq to St. Louis.

Your gift will make a difference! Thanks to supporters like you, in the past ten years we have witnessed the ability of music and dance to change lives. ​

Participant of the YES Academy Youth Orchestra in Lebanon

story:
Having spent years working in journalism and later as a creative director in advertising, my everyday task is dealing with insight. Addiction to smart devices is an insight we’ve in fact had for a long time. I mean look at Sydney, where they’re starting to install street lights at lower levels so that fewer people absorbed in their phones get run over! What have we come to?

Don’t get me wrong – the Internet and the possibilities it provides are amazing. If we didn’t have the Internet this fantastic site wouldn’t exist, and it’s right here that I’d ask for your help in making my dreams come true. Besides, it’s not up to me to take the fight to the Internet; I just want to remind people that there are plenty of opportunities in real life, too.

With your donations I’ll be setting up the Life Challenge Cards ordering site, where you’ll be able to order the cards for yourself, your family and your friends. Of course, one little site with no proper marketing isn’t going to get anywhere, so the majority of the money I raise will go towards advertising. Luckily I have the know-how I need in the advertising field, so I’m sure I can put the money to good use. Most of it I plan to invest in targeted Google and social media ads. I also plan to put together a much better showcase video than the one I currently have so that I can hold my head up when approaching potential investors.

Although I’ve already got a small team together, I’m planning to recruit more people with a good breadth of experience to help me think up new topics and new activities. If there’s one thing I want, it’s for the cards to never get boring. I want the topics to be exciting, and for there to be exciting topics for years to come!

Just imagine for a second that this idea of mine takes off. Just imagine in a year’s time loads of your friends knowing what Life Challenge Cards are. And just imagine yourself as one of those who helped make that a reality. We can all dream. In fact, we should all dream!

I’d be very grateful if you do, by sharing this link. Sharing is caring, right?

story:
Pictured: (From Left) La Peña Co-Executive Director Natalia Neira holds donated merchandise from Ana Tijoux.

Why Your Contributions Matter

From our humble yet revolutionary beginnings as a gathering place in response to the military coup in Chile, our mission continues to be the same: to be a safe space for immigrant and diasporic communities and to support peoples' movements through the arts!

La Peña Cultural Center needs your contributions to:

     • Provide a safe space for immigrant & diasporic communities to gather & organize

     • Maintain our cultures alive by hosting hundreds of events and classes per year

     • Empower children with culture-based arts education to build a strong sense of cultural identity

     • Promote intercultural solidarity through the arts

     • Offer scholarships for youth to our Mundos Musicales Summer Camp

     • Give a stage and a voice to both emerging and professional artists of color

    • Plus, La Peña will be donating 10% of this campaign's contributions to CIDSUR's Mapuche Legal Defense Fundraiser to eliminate state violence & discrimination against indigenous peoples in southern Chile.

What We Need & What You Get

     • Donate to this campaign to get exclusive Ana Tijoux screen prints, autographed pictures, tote bags, t-shirts, vinyl records and more!

     • This fundraiser will bring us $3,000 closer to La Peña’s yearly fundraising goal of $60,000! 

If you would like to make a contribution to La Peña's fundraising campaign without a perk, please visit: LAPENA.ORG

Other Ways You Can Help

     • Encourage your friends that love Ana Tijoux to support this campaign

     • Share this campaign on your social media

     • Follow La Peña on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter!

     • Join our email list to stay up to date with our upcoming events!

     • Become a “Friend of La Peña” by becoming a sustained monthly donor! Click here.

About Ana Tijoux

Photo courtesy of Paste Studio

As the daughter of exiled Chilean parents during the Pinochet regime, the multi-grammy nominated musician, Anita Tijoux, has a strong connection with La Peña’s history.

Tijoux has made a name for herself as an emcee who raps about anti-colonialism, anti-patriarchy, and other social issues to panpipe flutes, charangos, and other Latin American folk instruments. The New York Times has called her “South America’s answer to Lauryn Hill,” and music critic Jon Pareles described her beat and flow as “calmly assertive, never strident.”

With her unique style, Tijoux’s music has crossed Chile’s borders. Her song “1977” was featured in “Breaking Bad,” while her political views earned her an interview on the television show “Democracy Now!” She has been nominated for multiple Grammy Awards and won a Latin Grammy for Album of the Year for her collaboration with Jorge Drexler.

Special Thanks

La Peña Cultural Center thanks Ana Tijoux for taking time from her busy schedule to visit La Peña, meet with fans, and donate merchandise during her most recent tour through the Bay Area. We are so grateful for her kindness and generosity to ensure that our La Peña can continue to be a resource for our communities for years to come!

Pictures by Musiquito Media

Thank you for your support!

La Peña Cultural Center

3105 Shattuck Ave.

Berkeley, CA 94705

Lapena.org / 510-849-2568

story:
船到橋頭生活節喺2020年12月4-6日舉行，地點為坪洲、梅窩、芝麻灣及長洲四個離島社區，召集以當地居民為主嘅能人異士，創作統籌一系列跨媒介嘅活動，意在呈現海島文化之美，同時拓展島民身份嘅可能。我們現正籌募經費，詳情請睇下面嘅活動簡介。

 

Inter-island Festival is an arts and culture festival that will take place on 4-6 December 2020, in Peng Chau, Mui Wo, Chi Ma Wan and Cheung Chau, four outer islands in the south-western corner of Hong Kong. With a wide range of activities organised by talents on these islands and beyond, the Festival celebrates the insular culture on these islands and attempts to strengthen and expand the identity of ‘islander’. We need your support to make this happen, please read below to know more about how you can help.

 

 

長洲、芝麻灣、梅窩、坪洲呢四個地方，有一條橫水渡輪航線連繋住，沿途海岸景色吸引，同普遍印象中嘅香港大不相同。我哋認為，橫水渡除咗連住四個碼頭，亦都代表咗島嶼文化。一直以嚟，島民同周圍嘅環境建立起獨特嘅關係；我哋希望喺一切太遲之前，利用呢次機會，將島民同非島民聚集埋一齊嚟欣賞、保育離島嘅自然生態同生活文化。

 

Through the Inter-island Festival, we want to bring everyone together - on the islands and outside - to appreciate, defend and further develop the insular culture.

Over a long history, the residents in Cheung Chau, Chi Ma Wan, Mui Wo and Peng Chau have developed a peculiar life in relation to their landscape. The inter-island ferry that sails in between these four ports highlights the historical connections that link Hong Kong’s outer islands and the common culture of ‘life by the sea’ they developed and refined until now.

Not only is the sea and its surrounding environment vital to the residents on these islands, it is also a stunning scenery. Very different from what we are accustomed to seeing in Hong Kong, it nurtures invaluable ecosystems with specific animal and flora lives that contribute to making Hong Kong’s natural identity so rich and unique.

 

 

參與者可以用三種觀點了解海島生活：搜尋具有都市特色嘅線索、將生活點滴同大自然融和、感受藝術同傳統點樣喺島上進化。生活節為期三日，活動形式包括表演、工作坊、導賞團、裝置藝術、放映會同講座，喺各島各地透過豐富而貼地嘅節目展現海島生活嘅獨特之處，帶領參與者深入了解離島本土文化。

 

We invite participants to take a look at the insular life through three lenses: to look for the marks of a strong urban identity, to consider the intermingling of nature in every bit of life, and to expose their senses to the vibrant art forms and traditions that evolve on these islands.  

The 3-day festival comprises performances, workshops, tours, installations, screenings, talks, open houses and more, taking place across the islands. 

These activities are unique creations made by over 30 talents and groups from the islands and beyond. They answered the Festival’s call to offer a subtle, cosy and playful interpretation of the insular life for participants to softly dig into this culture and embrace its uniqueness.

 

​

 

生活節一連三日嘅成本包括材料費、製作費、合作單位酬金、人力資源開支、宣傳費用、保險同緊急備用金，預算係港幣$457,000，有幸得到香港藝術發展局同信言設計大使贊助嘅港幣$367,000，計劃籌募餘下平衡成本嘅港幣$97,000。

我哋而家由離島社區開始募捐，期望借呢個機會團結本地社區。而今次眾籌以預售生活節產品嘅方式，希望籌得尚欠金額中嘅港幣$50,000，同時透過眾籌引起大眾對香港離島文化同生態嘅關注。

我哋相信才華同勞力都應該要得到回報，因此籌得款項主要會撥入合作單位酬金同人力資源開支，超出目標金額嘅部分，將會分配到因預算不足而被逼擱置或者縮減規模嘅活動計劃。

感謝你嘅支持！

 

How are we funded?

The 3-whole-day festival’s costs include materials, production, fees of collaborators, personnel, promotion, insurance and contingency. Our budget totals at HK$457,000. We are grateful to have received sponsorships from the Hong Kong Arts Development Council and Design Trust that amount to HK$367,000 in sum. We are currently raising funds from the local communities to inscribe the Festival in the local traditions and enhance the relationship and sense of belonging with the local communities.

With this crowdfunding, we pre-sell some of our Festival souvenirs in hope to raise part of the remaining HK$97,000. We also believe it is a way for people to show their concern about Hong insular identity and our city landscape and invaluable nature. We hope you too will feel concerned and could contribute!

Where will the donation go?

Our target of HK$50,000 is the minimum we need to carry out the Festival. Thanks to our current sponsors, we can offer a (small) retribution to our collaborators, and pay for most of their material and production costs. However, the fees of personnel (staff, technicians, volunteers) and overall production (set-up, promotion,...) are the most in need. We hope everyone taking part in this Festival can receive a fair compensation for their work.

What happens if we exceed our target?

We had an ambitious plan to start with but the lack of fundings exacerbated by the current crisis forced us to scale down our plan. Therefore if we exceed our target, part of the donations will be allocated to our current collaborators so as to offer fair payments to their contributions. Next in line will be activities that are on hold or scaled-down because of the lack of funds.

 

​

 

我哋為生活節準備咗一系列代表離島文化嘅產品，邀請島民匠人、設計師協作出品，凸顯島嶼智慧同現代生活嘅和諧。
 

  • 船到橋頭名信片: 用島民角度為你拍低一套六張，長洲芝麻灣梅窩坪洲，仲有我哋嘅橫水渡；
  • 坪洲桑葉茶 X 手工皂: 天然手工小草皂房聯乘有機農夫品川一誠，用島產有機桑葉製作手工皂，坪洲天然獨家；
  • 長洲手織漁網袋: 長洲品牌島中坊研協作設計，生活節限定釣魚袋；
  • 橋頭福袋: 釣魚袋暗藏五款驚喜小物，留念島嶼生活文化。

 

Like Inter-island Festival itself, our perks crystallise the different facets of the insular culture.  They are unique collaborations with craftsmen and designers from the islands that show the beauty and value of local know-hows and their compatibility with modern lifestyle.

  • Inter-island Postcards: 6 postcards showing unique angles from the six locations - Cheung Chau, Chi Ma Wan, Mui Wo, Peng Chau and the inter-island ferry;
  • Peng Chau Tea Soap: Collaborating with Peng Chau-based Green Green Soap and Issei Shinagawa, we offer this unique natural soap that reveals the properties of locally growing mulberry leaf tea! The tea is collected by Japanese farmer Issei Shinagawa and used by Green Green Soap to make this soap. Both of them will be fairly retributed when you chose this perk;
  • Cheung Chau Handmade Fishing Bag: Cheung Chau-based Island Workbench reinterprets its unique collaboration with local fishermen specially for the Festival! Reusing traditional craftsmanship, these bags show how local crafts can create beautiful items fit for our modern urban lifestyle; 
  • Surprise box: Together with the fishing bag, the soap and the postcards, you will find a set of five finely-selected little gifts that will let explore the local culture further.

 

​

 

船到橋頭生活節嘅發起人係三個坪洲居民：城市規劃研究者Myriem Alnet、陸日小店老闆之一陳俊傑，與及藝術家同策展人葉啟俊。三人關注島嶼文化，其中Myriem同阿傑出版咗探討島嶼生活特式嘅雜誌<<島民>>，阿俊亦曾經喺島上籌辦藝術活動。面對當前變化，我哋想藉住生活節將島民同非島民連結，為保存同發展島嶼文化出一分力。

另外，我哋組成咗橋頭團隊：長洲聯絡人黎穎欣、梅窩聯絡人陳希雯同吳若琪、文案寫作編輯施揚、平面設計Studio Orbit ，以更有效籌組生活節。

 

Inter-island Festival is initiated by Myriem Alnet, Chan Chun-kit and Yip Kai-chun. We have lived on Peng Chau for a few years.

Myriem is an urbanist; Kit is one of the founders of Sun Sat Store on Peng Chau; and Chun is an artist-curator. Kit and Myriem have founded ‘ISLANDERS’, a zine on the island cultures, and Chun has organised small-scale art events on Peng Chau before.  

Seeing the changes happening now and in the future, we want to take one step further to contribute to the islands and organise this Festival to connect everyone. We are joined on the sailing by Vanessa Lai Wing-yan (Cheung Chau correspondent), Chan Hei-man and Kay Ng (Mui Wo correspondents), Adrian Si (content writer & editor), Studio Orbit (graphic design).
