story:
“Youth, given the tools and opportunity, will surprise us with their clear observations and creative solutions to what is wrong in the world.” – Shontina Vernon, Creative Justice Mentor Artist

 

Help send Creative Justice youth leaders to the Open Engagement conference in Chicago, where they will present the workshop:

#FreeTheYouth: Art as an Alternative to Incarceration

Youth facilitators will teach conference attendees why jailing kids doesn’t help them or make our communities safer. They will show the ways Creative Justice effectively uses art as a detention alternative, and will examine the questions: What is justice? How do racial and gender identities impact the ways we experience justice? What is the role of art in our freedom?

Participation in Open Engagement is the first leadership development opportunity of this caliber available to the youth of Creative Justice! 

In addition to sharing their perspectives and ideas with a national audience, the youth will attend social practice master classes and other conference programming, building with renowned artists like Theaster Gates, Ai-jen Poo and Marisa Morán Jahn.

"The weight of historical injustice interrupts daily life nationally and internationally. There is no better time than now, and no better city than Chicago, for examining pathways to create justice and exploring the manifold artistic strategies that demand and enact fairness, and equality." 

   - Romi Crawford & Lisa Lee, Open Engagement 2017 Curators

 

About Creative Justice

Creative Justice was launched by 4Culture in 2015 as an arts-based alternative to incarceration for youth in King County, Washington. Rather than being locked in jail, court-involved young people remain in the community where they participate in 3-4 month project sessions with mentor artists whose work is grounded in social justice. Through multi-disciplinary arts experiences and community-centered dialog, the youth consider many of the root causes of incarceration like racism and other forms of oppression. At the end of each session, they use art to amplify their voices and promote change, leading and producing community based actions in which they offer their own ideas, vision, and creativity to address the issues that most impact them.

In exchange for their creative work, Creative Justice youth receive community service credit and stipends that help pay court fines. Program participation is also used as mitigation in their cases, with benefits ranging as far as full case dismissal. The impact of the experience, however, is much farther reaching than court outcomes alone. Participants develop authentic relationships with supportive mentors, are introduced to the artist-activist community, and are encouraged to use their leadership skills to bring about meaningful social change. In these ways, Creative Justice offers a new vision of what justice can be, reminding the court system that secure confinement is not necessary.

The Creative Justice Youth Leadership Team provides a way for program participants to engage with mentors long after their project sessions end via monthly gatherings and special projects. These emerging leaders are helping guide the program’s evolution, continuing to contribute to the dialog about juvenile justice reform through their individual and collective creativity. Leadership development training opportunities are coupled with public presentations of art, pop-up exhibits, panel discussions, and community workshops.

Creative Justice participants initiated the #FreeTheYouth campaign with music, a video, and a t-shirt design. The message serves as anthem for the Youth Leadership Team's upcoming workshop at Open Engagement.


About Open Engagement 2017 

Open Engagement (OE) is the largest artist-led conference dedicated to expanding the dialogue around, and creating a site of care for, the field of socially engaged art. Founded in 2007, OE has evolved into an unparalleled hub for practitioners and audiences to assemble. OE supports emerging and established artists and organizers, highlights the voices of students alongside professionals, and collaborates closely with national institutions to further the networks of support for socially engaged art. OE is committed to the power of art to enact radical social change.

Too often, artists and activists working across a wide spectrum of issues ranging from immigration, food and environmental justice, urban planning, gentrification, police violence, and many other vital and timely reckonings are isolated from one another.

In 2017, OE is focused on the theme of JUSTICE. The conference will take place at the University of Illinois at Chicago and a constellation of sites across the city. How can artists contribute to the work for justice? How can these movements be more effective with the work of artists? This conference is intended to break down these silos, serve as an educational resource, facilitate crucial dialogue, and provide opportunities to highlight successful artistic and community engagements. OE is a site to learn from one another and to provide opportunities for attendees to access valuable skills and tools that push and support their work in embedded contexts.

 

Why This Campaign?

Open Engagement participation presents a unique leadership development opportunity for our youth, but the cost cannot be funded through the Creative Justice budget. We are launching this campaign to raise the funds needed to cover project expenses, travel costs and accommodations for the youth and chaperones. Every dollar you donate (up to our goal) will directly support youth participation in the Open Engagement conference. Should we surpass our goal, any additional funds will help maintain the activities of our currently under-funded program.

To thank you for your support, we have an array of gifts from digital downloads of youth art to #FreeTheYouth bracelets and T-shirts, and even some cool swag generously donated by our friends at Sub Pop Records! We'll be posting new perks throughout the campaign, with surprises along the way.

story:
Hi, I’m Tango.

I think we need to start a conversation about how we get change in Washington. We need immediate investigation into the administration, but we also have to start looking at the larger problems our government is facing. Congress has been broken for a long time.

I’m starting a traveling conversation about what a 21st Century America should look like.

It's called the Rally to Reason, an 18-month, sustained movement around the country that attempts to talk to as many people as possible.

If this IndieGoGo is successful I’m packing up my ride with the goal of carrying a steady conversation around the country. I'll be staying on the couches of friends and strangers, sleeping out of a tent, and call the road my home for the next two years. Each day I'll meet new people with their own stories and their own ideas about how we move forward. Then I'll take their ideas with me and share it online and with the friends I make in the next two down the road. I'll also invite others to travel along with me, attempting to grow the Rally into a movement.

Along the way I’m going to be documenting my journey. I expect to create two regular types of content:

  1. A weekly podcast covering the efforts in getting the Rally off the ground. I’ll release a podcast each week that talks about my expectations going into a new area, collections of interviews from the people I meet there, and lessons I learned on the way out.  
  2. Recordings of listening circles from around the country. While the podcast will contain clips of the conversation, occasionally we’ll want to release recordings of a complete listening circle. Typically these will be audio only, but we’ll work to get video when available.
  3. Essays about life on the road. Occasionally I'll write a long-form article about my travels. (You can see an example of my writing style from my time in Rwanda here.)

Your contribution will also be making the Rally possible. I want to get things started as we move into spring, which means aiming for Earth Day, April 22nd in Denver. You can follow our progress on twitter, see upcoming events on Facebook, and learn how to join us on the road at RallyToReason.com.

Thank you for your time. I appreciate it,

-Tango

What's different about a Rally versus a March?

We're big fans of protest events like the upcoming March for Science. They bring together activists and first-time protestors to meet in person, getting involved in their own backyard.

The Rally is attempting to drive the conversation from a different direction. Instead of a one day event centered on a specific issue in a hundred locations, we're going to focus on the concerns of one city at a time. We'll shake hands, start listening circles, and talk about what we want America to be. 

 

Contribute to something different.

It's always seemed kinda funny to us that we call them "movements" when people mostly stay in the same place. What if it wasn't? Imagine thousands of cars in a line, coasting down the highway, taking the voices of America straight to the White House and into Congress.

Once we're out on the road, you'll get access to the videos, photos, writings, and other creative pursuits that come out of this journey. We'll post protestor interviews and organized listening circles to YouTube. Our Instagram will be filled with the signs, smiles, and stories from marches all over the country. And we'll be experimenting with shooting Virtual Reality videos across our nation, from national parks to community town hall events. 

But that's the minimum that happens if we reach our goal. The big idea? To get a sustained, traveling rally of people and vehicles moving from coast-to-coast. We'll hold listening circles to get a better understanding of the diverse needs of our nation. In the process, we'll keep an eye out for interesting ideas that might help our nation move forward, past the gridlock in Washington. When possible we'll meet with local representatives, help out volunteer organizations when they need an extra pair (or hundred pairs) of hands, and most importantly get promises to vote in 2018.

We're trying something a little different than a one day march. There is always a risk the new doesn't catch on.  If that is the case, even in failure we'll learn and document the results. Then we'll keep marching forward.

Contributions to the Rally keep the conversation moving. We know there are a lot of worthy causes that have your attention. 

Start a conversation about what comes next.

The Rally is intended to turn our outrage into resolve, jump-starting the conversation towards creative solutions to our existing problems. During the week we’ll be holding smaller events where we can sit down with local leaders and activists to understand what their biggest concerns are. At these listening circles we will be looking for interesting ideas that pull the discussion forward about what a 21st Century America looks like.

On weekends we’ll hold larger events that are a combination of listening circles and demonstrations. We’ll invite participants from earlier listening circles to have a larger discussion about common issues we heard during the week.

The conversation will continue to evolve as we move from city-to-city. At the final rally in Washington we’ll bring in the speakers we've met that left the biggest impact on our discussion and discuss everything we’ve learned over the course of the Rally.

 

About the Organizer

My background is in User Experience design. That essentially means sitting down with people to talk about how they do something and then figuring out a better way for them to do it. This is usually focused on the products we buy, in my case companies like Procter & Gamble, Motorola  and Hasbro. I've spent a lot of time interviewing people from all walks of life, from CEOs to their night security.

In 2014 I had a chance to work with the Kigali Genocide Memorial in Rwanda. We focused on how to turn visitors that were feeling like they were helpless with despair into activists that could effect change back home.  Turns out that lesson stuck with me. I want to take our anger and frustration and turn it into resolve. 

(If you would like to know more about my time in Rwanda the organizer has great explanation of the work here.)

 

Let's get Indivisible.

One of the biggest keys to the Rally’s success will be partnering with local Indivisible groups. We want to get to know you, learn what drives you, and build a face-to-face network of activists across the country. 

Please contact us about scheduling joint events if you have started an Indivisible group of your own. We’re doing our best to reach out to as many organizers as we can, but with over 7000 groups (!) we have a lot of work to do.

 

Coming to a location near you!

Where is the rally headed? Anywhere and everywhere! Here is the expected route and timetable:

Spring/Summer, 2017 | 3,157 mi | route

Denver, CO  | April 22, 2017

Standing Rock, SD | April 29, 2017

Billings, MT | May 6, 2017

Seattle, WA | May 20, 2017

Portland, OR | May 27, 2017

Sacramento, CA | June 10, 2017

San Jose, CA | June 24, 2017

Bakersfield, CA | July 8, 2017

Los Angeles, CA | July 22, 2017

San Diego, CA | August 12, 2017

Fall/Winter, 2017 | 2,601 mi | route

Phoenix, AZ | September 2, 2017

Tuba City, AZ | September 16, 2017

Albuquerque, NM | September 30, 2017

El Paso, TX | October 14, 2017

Austin, TX | October 28, 2017

Houston, TX | November 11, 2017

Baton Rouge, LA | December 9, 2017

Jackson, MS | December 16, 2017

Winter/Spring, 2018 | 1,687 mi | route

Montgomery, AL | January 6, 2018

Atlanta, GA | January 20, 2018

Charlotte, NC | February 3, 2018

Knoxville, TN | February 10, 2018

Nashville, TN | February 24, 2018

Lexington, KY | March 10, 2018

Cincinnati, OH | March 24, 2018

Indianapolis, IN | March 31, 2018

Chicago, IL | April 14, 2018

Spring/Summer 2018 | 1,318 mi | route

Flint, MI | April 28, 2018

Detroit, MI | May 5, 2018

Toledo, OH | May 12, 2018

Columbus, OH | May 19, 2018

Akron, OH | May 26, 2018

Pittsburgh, PA | June 9, 2018

Buffalo, NY | June 23, 2018

Syracuse, NY | June 30, 2018

Montpelier, VT | July 14, 2018

Summer/Fall 2018  | 703 mi | route

Portland, ME | July 21, 2018

Concord, NH | August 4, 2018

Boston, MA | August 18, 2018

Providence, RI | August 25, 2018

Hartford, CT | September 1, 2018

New York, NY | September 15, 2018

Philadelphia, PA | September 29, 2018

Annapolis, MA | October 6, 2018

Baltimore, MA | October 20, 2018

Washington, D.C. | November 3, 2018

April 22nd, 2017 to Nov 6th, 2018 | 9,466 mi in 564 days

 

COME RALLY WITH US!

More than your donation we would LOVE to have you on the road with us. Pack up your car, your camper, or your motorcycle and join up with the Rally!

Meet us in Denver to attend the March for Science protests happening April 22nd. We'll hang out there for a couple days to finalize the first leg of the plan with whoever is coming, then head north towards Standing Rock. Along the way we'll look to stop at some rock climbing, kayaking, and hiking spots.

Or, you can take a look at the schedule above. When we're coming by your area come out and join us for a while! If we're headed somewhere you've been meaning to visit start planning your vacation for the time we'll be in the area.

You can caravan for a day, a week, a month, or the full 18-months. Everyone is welcome from any walk of life! Over the next few weeks we'll be covering our plans for how we expect to travel and what you'll want to think about before hitting the road at RallyToReason.com.

Finally, if you just want to find us and give us a high five of encouragement that will be more than welcome! (We also take hugs. Hugs are awesome.)

story:
Hello. I'm Shanté.  I'm a Philadelphian and a natural born creator.  Whether it's producing music or designing jackets and sunglasses, my passion is in the arts. 

In 2014, 3 years after moving to LA, I fell on hard times and ended up homeless.   I lost everything and I mean ev-er-y thiiiig, but also gained everything at the same time. How you ask?  I lost everything that I thought was leading me in the right direction and found a greater sense of purpose.  Yes, being homeless can take a mental toll on you.  I've seen both sides of the fence; from the Hollywood Hills to the Hollywood Alley, but I have no regrets. I believe God allows you to go through a multitude of experiences, good and bad, to help you gain clarity and perspective which ultimately leads you towards your purpose in life.  I knew this wasn't the end for me.  My faith grew tremendously during this time period and I had some of the most soul-filling experiences ever in life. 

I loved connecting with people from all over the world with good values, morals, and sincere hearts.  We had nothing to offer each other but genuine love.  Strangers helping strangers because we are human first before any added labels. 

Hopeful, resilient, and extremely resourceful, I was determined to make it through. 

Fast forward, Now my mission is to help and encourage others. Life does get better if you just hold on and put your faith in God,  because we all deserve to experience the best of what life has to offer. 

 

HOW YOUR DONATION HELPS:

10% of the proceeds will be donated to the church that helped me get my life back on track. 

50% goes into a Homeless Initiative Fund

Short-Term: This fund will help The 400 feed the homeless and supply them with basic necessities across the cities of Los Angeles & Philadelphia to start. 

Long-Term:  A portion of our profits from the brand will go into this fund to accumulate enough money to build small second chance housing, where the people can get a fresh start at life and feel human again. 

Collaborate with organizations in the health care field to get people the help they need to step back into society with confidence. 

 

The Remaining Donations will go towards:

Building a website which will be half community, half magazine. 

An App for the website

Enhance Social Media Pages

Marketing to expand and reach more people

Design and Produce top quality apparel that represents the brand.

 

YOU CAN FOLLOW WHAT WE'VE BEEN CURATING ON INSTAGRAM: @the400_te 

 

We thank you in advance! Feel free to interact with us on social media.  We love meeting and talking to new people.  God Bless!

story:
How This All Got Started

We love dogs. We're guessing you love dogs too (or that you clicked the wrong link, but WELCOME anyway!). Pretty quickly after starting down this road we realized there are A LOT of people in Acadiana who love dogs and want a chill place to hang with the their dogs and also enjoy themselves with other dog-loving friends and new acquaintances. 

  • Barkopolis Park + Pub is a concept and company that has already proven its demand and popularity through grass-roots social media and pop-up concept parks in Lafayette.
  • Our #1 goal is building community among dog lovers and a more dog-friendly culture in Acadiana. Barkopolis is our #HappyPlace and we're certain it will quickly become yours too!
  • This campaign will not only help us bring Barkopolis to life for so many people who want a dog-inclusive community space, but it will also serve as a conduit for more good work supporting animal welfare throughout Acadiana, one of our founding objectives. 
  • By supporting Barkopolis, you're supporting everything we stand for - community inclusivity, creative excellence, and business for a better purpose.

What We Need & What You Get

Every contribution is a partnership and commitment:

  • This campaign will help us build up investment capital to get Barkopolis Park + Pub up and running in a permanent home. We take your contributions very seriously and we are truly humbled by your support. We want to use your funds to help bring about the kind of place you want to be a part of!
  • Our contribution levels are structured to fit your comfort level of support. Wanna be our cheerleader? There's an option for that. Already a big fan and wanna go all in? You can do that too!
  • All funds, whether we meet our goal or not, will be put toward opening a permanent location of Barkopolis Park + Pub in Lafayette. The more funding we get, the quicker it'll happen.

The Impact

  • A contribution to Barkopolis is a vote for doggie Nirvana, and that's exactly what we want to create! Because as all dog lovers know, when our pups are happy, we're happy. #LifeGoals
  • This isn't just a fleeting effort. This is the culmination of all the right people, at just the right time, for exactly the right reasons, to build something amazing. We want Barkopolis Park + Pub to be something people get excited about, come back over and over for, and share with their friends.
  • We love dog people. There's an unspoken understanding of care and compassion that we know exists inside every person who's ever loved a dog. Or any animal. That's YOU! We like being around people like you, because people like you inspire us, and what better place to be than a big crowd of animal-loving inspiring people?!

Risks & Challenges

Building a business isn't easy. And it isn't without its impasses. In fact, we count on running into a few. We promise to navigate those challenges as carefully and strategically as possible. 

  • Our objective will always be to resolve hurdles as efficiently as possible, balancing conservation of the three most important resources to any business - time, effort, and money.
  • We also promise to operate ourselves and our business as fairly as possible. We want to be good ambassadors of the local business community, the dog-friendly community, and the patrons and pets we serve. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute financially? No worries!

  • Share and like this page and tell all your friends! There's no such thing as too much support, AMIRIGHT?
  • Join us at our periodic pop-ups! The more people who love this idea, the more fuel we have to keep going!

story:
I am Michelle Andrea Smith the founder of the Pembroke Taparelli International Artivist Festival a Music, Art, and Film Festival focused on social justice.  We believe in the power of art to heal, and bring justice to those disenfranchised.  As artists we use the written and spoken words, canvas, paint brush, music, dance, film to tell stories that inspire and motivate change.

PTAFF provides a platform for artists to "Create Change" through their art.  We give a voice to those most affected by injustice, through our film screenings, art exhibits and public forums we will tackle issues affecting the marginalized and disenfranchised. 

We need your help this year as we gear up to screen over 40 films at LA Live's Regal Theatre.  We want to create an opportunity for filmmakers, activists, community leaders, government officials to come to learn how we can work together to create change.  Let us "Make Art not War" and use that Art to fuel global change.

PTAFF 2018

For 2018, the Pembroke Taparelli Arts and Film Festival will be held at L.A. Live’s Regal Theatre. The festival is set to focus on Health and Environmental injustice; bringing awareness to the inequities within healthcare, the impact of food deserts, airborne pollutants, and climate change on minority, poor and marginalized communities. New additions to the festival will also engage youth (12-18) and young adults (19-25) to be the change that they seek through a music concert and 52 - hour speed film competition focusing on health and fitness.

The festival will cater to arts enthusiasts, filmmakers, and citizens from around the globe; screening features, shorts, and documentaries, displaying artwork, and conducting engaging panels with health/environmental professionals and activists.

This year’s art exhibit offers us an opportunity to explore the works of female artists as they examine gender inequalities and current thoughts around health and health care that contribute to the disparities and inequalities for underserved and marginalized communities.

 

"HEAL OUR YOUTH"

PTAFF seeks to inspire, uplift and challenge our youth and young adults to take action, to bring a positive change to their communities through their performance of conscious Hip Hop, Rap, Rock, R&B and EDM.

The concert is open to youth groups, middle and high school students, and youth from varying socio-economic groups. The event will be culturally and ethnically diverse.

PTAFF BEGINNINGS - 2016

The festival began with the sold-out world premiere of Road to Redemption at the historic Raleigh Studios in Hollywood. Directed by Berlin Film Fest and Cannes Alum, Jeta Amata (The Amazing Grace, Alexa Affair and Mary Slessor), the feature length film starred GRAMMY winner Akon, OSCAR nominee Margaret Avery, and Nigerian Film Star Vica Bianco.

Over the course of the 4-day festival, forty films were screened in feature, short, and documentary categories. Committed to diversity, PTAFF featured female filmmakers, LBGTQ, and people with disabilities.

PTAFF hosted the Los Angeles Mayor’s Office, the Los Angeles Police Department and non-profits such as the Violence Prevention Coalition of Greater Los Angeles, Fight for Peace of Brazil, and the Los Angeles Mission.

 

PTAFF 2017

In 2017, PTAFF welcomed legendary actor Bill Cobbs (The Taking of Pelham One Two Three, Trading Places, Night at The Museum) as its Ambassador.

PTAFF catered to arts enthusiasts, filmmakers, and citizens from across the globe and expanded its impact 2-day festival to the East Coast: PTAFF New York.

PTAFF New York kicked off with Mbongeni Ngema's Asinamali - a musical of prisoners finding resilience, liberation and forgiveness with the help of a black activist. The film was produced by the same creative partnership of the international box office hit Sarafina! starring EGOT winner Whoopi Goldberg.

PTAFF 2017 screened for the OSCAR committee Thomas Lennon’s Knife Skills - a short doc following a by-the-books French restaurant giving formerly incarcerated adults a foundation in the restaurant business. The doc subsequently earned an OSCAR nomination.

PTAFF’s art exhibition featured the work of currently and formerly incarcerated men. The featured artist, Fulton Leroy Washington, shared his experience on receiving his clemency for his famous painting Emancipation Proclamation.

PTAFF also held an 8 week workshop entitled Voices of the Incarcerated at Valley Correctional Facility. A short screenplay was developed, produced, and presented by the incarcerated at both festival locations.
story_txt: I am Michelle Andrea Smith the founder of the Pembroke Taparelli International Artivist Festival a Music, Art, and Film Festival focused on social justice.  We believe in the power of art to heal, and bring justice to those disenfranchised.  As artists we use the written and spoken words, canvas, paint brush, music, dance, film to tell stories that inspire and motivate change.PTAFF provides a platform for artists to "Create Change" through their art.  We give a voice to those most affected by injustice, through our film screenings, art exhibits and public forums we will tackle issues affecting the marginalized and disenfranchised. We need your help this year as we gear up to screen over 40 films at LA Live's Regal Theatre.  We want to create an opportunity for filmmakers, activists, community leaders, government officials to come to learn how we can work together to create change.  Let us "Make Art not War" and use that Art to fuel global change.PTAFF 2018For 2018, the Pembroke Taparelli Arts and Film Festival will be held at L.A. story:
Cincinnati Scenic Railway, a 501(3)c nonprofit organization, rescued a Chessie System bay window caboose from the  scrapper's torch earlier this summer. Now we need your help to complete the mechanical and cosmetic restoration. Several thousand dollars have already been raised and invested in saving this caboose. Help us get this project over the finish line and get this piece of American railroad history back into service!

#savethechessie

 

Our Story

About This Project

C&O 904137 has an interesting history.  Originally built by Fruit Growers Express in 1979 for the Chessie System, the caboose was damaged in 2010. The damage prevented the car from being shipped by rail and it was placed in a siding near Queensgate Yard in Cincinnati, OH. The bad ordered caboose would end up staying in that disused siding over 10 years.

Earlier this summer officials at CSX Transportation reached out to Cincinnati Scenic Railway to save 904137 which was slated to be removed by a scrapper. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, the nonprofit organization was able to pull together enough funding to rescue the historic caboose. Working with Case Towing, it was transported at the eleventh hour to the Lebanon Mason Monroe Railroad in Lebanon, OH.

Despite being exposed to vandals and the elements for over a decade, 904137 is in remarkably good condition retaining nearly all of its original interior fixtures. It will make an amazing addition to Cincinnati Scenic Railway's expanding collection of operating rolling stock.

If parts can be sourced in a timely manner and funding goals achieved, volunteers expect to have the caboose fully restored within 6-12 months. The caboose will be used as a shove platform in freight and passenger excursion service.

 

About Cincinnati Scenic Railway

Cincinnati Scenic Railway is a 501(3)c nonprofit organization operating the Lebanon Mason Monroe Railroad and the Ohio Rail Experience.

The organization is proud to fund nearly all of it's restoration efforts out the fare-box while serving nearly 55,000 passengers a year.

The Lebanon Mason Monroe Railroad, is a successful shortline tourist railroad based in Lebanon, OH. The Ohio Rail Experience, is a one-of-a-kind operator of rare mileage excursions over nearly 400 miles of track.

Cincinnati Scenic Railway is home to 3 vintage EMD locomotives and over 25 historic railcars.

The organization is actively fundraising for the acquisition of Chessie System B&O GP30 6955. More information on that project can be found here: https://tinyurl.com/y4l8vjl8

#savethechessie

 

Our Plans

Restoration 

The caboose is in great shape but needs more than just a little TLC. Over $7,000 has already been invested into preserving C&O 904137, but we need your help to complete the project. We plan to complete the following work as a part of the restoration:

- Replace windows damaged by vandals.

- Replace the missing door on the "B" end.

- Underneath, a lot of repair work is needed to get the car into revenue service, including, but not limited to: replacing the damaged self centering device, changing out the brake valves, and completing repairs to the draft gear assembly.

- Restore the original diesel oil fired stove.

- Patch holes in interior made by an investigating scrapper.

- Paint the caboose exterior.

 

Operation

C&O 904137 will be used by Cincinnati Scenic Railway on their Lebanon Mason Monroe Railroad in Lebanon, OH

It will be used as a shove platform in freight and passenger excursion service. The public will have the opportunity to ride in the caboose on passenger trains.

The LM&M Railroad operates 5 miles of track from Lebanon, OH to Hageman Junction in partnership with the Cincinnati Railway Company. The railroad is a popular regional attraction with well patronized passenger excursions running year-round.

 

Use of Funds Beyond Goal

Funds raised beyond the $2,800 goal and any unspent funds will benefit Cincinnati Scenic Railway's campaign to purchase and restore Chessie System B&O GP30 6955. More information on that project can be found here: https://tinyurl.com/y4l8vjl8

#savethechessie

 

Rewards

$15: Donate $15 and receive an exclusive Chessie System Caboose Magnet.

$25: Donate $25 and receive an exclusive Chessie System GP30 pin.

$75: Donate $75 and receive an exclusive Chessie System "Queensgate Yard" hat.

$90: Donate $90 and receive the magnet, pin, and hat combo!

$350: Donate $350 and you will be invited to a a day where you will get a chance to operate a locomotive on the LM&M Railroad.* Includes "Save the Chessie" combo.

$5,000: Donate $5,000 and receive a private excursion, with an optional stop for lunch or dinner in Mason. Up to 100 people or 12 in a special caboose trip.* Includes "Save the Chessie" Combo.

 

*The equipment used will be determined by the railroad. The donor will be provided a list of dates and times cab rides/charters are available after the conclusion of the campaign. Only one passenger can ride in the locomotive.  and charters are approximately 1 hour and 15 minutes long. Cab riders will need to sign a waiver and comply with crew member instructions. Cab riders will also need to come dressed in long plants, sturdy closed toed shoes, and a sleeved shirt. Other PPE will be provided.

Up to 100 people or 12 in a special caboose trip.* Includes "Save the Chessie" Combo. *The equipment used will be determined by the railroad. Only one passenger can ride in the locomotive.  and charters are approximately 1 hour and 15 minutes long. Cab riders will need to sign a waiver and comply with crew member instructions. Cab riders will also need to come dressed in long plants, sturdy closed toed shoes, and a sleeved shirt. Other PPE will be provided.

story:
Overview 

Memory Kaleidoscope is a delightful card game that allows us to connect with families, friends, coworkers and strangers. The artwork featured on the cards helps us surface big and small moments of our lives. Players will deepen their understanding of one another through listening and discussing the memories shared. The game rewards those with an open heart and a curious mind.

Who We Are

We are dreamers from Design Dream Lab. We are a non-profit creative collective based in NYC striving to bring positive impacts to the local community by applying the empathy-based Design Thinking mindset. We bring our passion and love for humanity to everything we build, with everyone we connect, and to all our projects. The dreamers who are working on this game have a lot of heart, and they also come with expertise in game design, user research, cultural education, behavioral therapy, and community building.

The Backstory

Developing this game over the past 14 months has been a labor of love. It all began with a simple email. On September 11, 2017, Design Dream Lab got an email inquiry from the Queens Public Library in New York City:

“We’d like to build a ... game for families to play together during the holidays...to introduce story sharing as a fun activity and (hopefully) begin a family’s dialog ... to not only sharing their heritage within their own family, but sharing it with their library’s local history collections.”

Design Dream Lab members (AKA dreamers) got together and created a game to be played during holidays with family. However, during the development of the game, we didn’t have enough families to test out the game. So we tested with different groups- with complete strangers, with college interns, with our neighbors, and with our co-workers. 

And something magical happened. Strangers, colleagues, and neighbors began sharing stories of their childhood, their recent travels, and memories they haven’t shared in a long time with anyone. And those memories connected people in such a meaningful and delightful ways.

That is when we decided to expand the reach of this game to communities beyond families.

We discovered that sharing memories, listening, curiosity, and empathy - which are essential ingredients in playing this game - could bring people together in such meaningful and surprising ways.

Why It Works

Conventional conversations often make us focus on being right as opposed to hearing others and being heard. In developing this game, we asked:

  • How might we create a safe space for the storyteller to share stories beyond the surface level topics?
  • How might we encourage listeners to stay curious about the person who shares the story without judgement?
  • How might we allow the players to see the connections with other players beyond their own stories?
  • How might we reflect on the stories shared and appreciate being together?

You will find the answers by playing this card game. It was developed to bring us together as human beings - with curiosity, with authenticity, with empathy, with connections, and with deep gratitude for the memories players share with one another.

We playtested this game with a variety of people and settings - with families at a street fair, with seniors at senior centers, with college students at an orientation, with leaders at startups.

We heard repeatedly that Memory Kaleidoscope helped players connect with one another in a way that felt fun, safe, intimate, meaningful, and satisfying.

People got to know one another through their shared memories and had a sense of relatedness when common themes arose.  Family members who have known each other for 20+ years also learned something new about one another that never surfaced before in years of interaction.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Starting without a budget, our core team members put in hundreds of hours developing and testing the game with homemade prototype cards. With your contribution, we can issue a second printing to make the game available to more people so that we can spread the joy of human connection!

We have already heard from players interested in adapting the game for children in therapy, homebound seniors, teachers in schools, hospital cancer programs, and corporate team building. Your contribution will help us further explore these ideas, facilitate sessions with you in your community of interest and develop game guides for your specific goal and similar communities like yours. 

We need your help to raise $7500 to help us print more Memory Kaleidoscope decks and bring them to more communities.

Community Trailblazers: For backers contributing $500, it gives you 1 box of Memory Kaleidoscope + a 2hr in-person facilitation session for a group of no more than 15 participants at an NYC location.  

Create-the-Wave Leader: For backers contributing $200, it gives you 1 box of Memory Kaleidoscope + a 1hr virtual train-the-trainer session. 

Individual Community Heroes: For backers contributing $25, you get 1 box of Memory Kaleidoscope without facilitation. 

The Impact

There are few games that encourage people to share their memories while cultivating genuine curiosity about others. Knowing others through their lived experience helps us form deeper connections with one another. Using art to evoke these memories results in unexpected moments of recall and connection between events shared amongst players that would not happen in regular conversation.

Risks & Challenges

We understand that this card game is not for everybody. This game is not for someone who plays games only to win and compete. There are no winners or losers in this game. This is not a game for someone who finds it hard to sit still for longer than 15 minutes. In addition, active listening is a skill that develops with practice, therefore, although this game has been played by children, it is not intended for those 10 years old and younger.

We hope to focus our effort so that Memory Kaleidoscope can reach those who can benefit from it most. This game will benefit those that wish to foster team building, community building, and relationship building.  By facilitating games of Memory Kaleidoscope with you in your community, we believe that we can further improve the game design and make it more relevant to the needs of more communities.

Other Ways You Can Help

We are thrilled that we are able to have our first printing in time for the holidays.  There is a limited edition of 300 decks, which won’t last long!   

Whether you are able to contribute to our Memory Kaleidoscope campaign now or later, please forward the campaign to your friends, family, and colleagues and help us spread the word. We need your help to promote some peace, love and understanding! 

We'd love to hear your feedback. Reach us at play@MemoryKaleidoscope.com

story:
Short Summary

This campaign is run Isabelle Desjeux, an artist, working in collaboration with 3Pumpkins, a non-profitarts company working with communities.

Isabelle has been playing with pinhole photography for the past 5 years. As she also regularly works with children, she has developed ways and methods to share the technique with children and families. This project aims to empower the children by teaching them how to make their own camera, take pictures of their neighbourhood and share the result.

The Pin-Hole Photography in the Neighbourhood Project is co-created with children from Lengkok Bahru as part of a community placemaking project, Seeing The Obvious, where we explore different uses and designs of public spaces to connect people. 

When you contribute to this project, you help fulfill a dream children did not even know they had: to independently become photographers of their own neighbourhood, open up interest into a simple yet effective technology, spend time on an open-ended project, become an active part of their community as connectors, documenters, facilitators. And they will be so proud when their photographs are exhibited at the end, showing their work not just to their own community but to the public at large! 

What You Will Be Contributing To

This is what we need:

  • A space. The King of Fruits shop has already been sponsored by the boss of the neighbourhood coffeeshop.Yay!
  • Dark Room set-up and consumables.This is where children will be loading their camera before stepping out to take a picture and coming back to develop it. The room might also function as a pin-hole camera body itself, where viewers can walk in and find themselves literally inside a camera box. Consumables are Photo paper, Developer and fixative. $500
  • Artist and Facilitator Fees. Between 17th January to 21th February, the space will be open to children who want to learn the technique, get help making their camera, or get support taking their picture. 2 adults will be present in the space for this time period, daily from approximately 3 pm till 6 pm. $2000
  • Exhibition set-up. The exhibition will take place from 15th February till 21st February. We will need to cover the cost of printing, framing, lighting, window text decals, as well as an augmented reality part. $500

If we don’t reach our full goal, we will run the show on a shoestring and simplify the project. If more funds are received, it could make the project sustainable by funding the project in neighbourhoods such as Boon Lay Drive, where 3Pumpkins is also reaching out to underserved children and youth in the neighbourhood.

Rewards:

We have gathered a number of perks ranging from collectable artwork to experiences. Whether you live nearby or far away, whether you want to make a large or small contribution, we have you covered! Go check out the perks!

The Impact
Pin-hole Photography in the Neighbourhood project is brought together by Isabelle Desjeux and 3Pumpkins’ beliefs in our art practice: the unlimited possibilities of art-science explorations and enabling social sustainability through the arts. 

 

Art in the neighborhood can have a lasting impact on the members of the community, especially in a neighbourhood like Lengkok Bahru where there are children who do not have access to arts and science explorations outside school curriculum. The work seeks to empower these children with the knowledge of photography physics, cultivating their problem-solving skills and self-esteem. The children are also guided to observe their environment and appreciate their surroundings in ways that people have forgotten to notice, inspiring and connecting others as they move around the neighbourhood taking photographs.

 

For a few weeks in December, Isabelle has been become a familiar ‘Lady in Pink’ figure in Lengkok Bahru as she visits daily to take pictures using her own camera and portable darkroom. for a few weeks in December. In the process of this pilot experience, more than 10 cameras were made and over 30 photographs were developed with over 15 children, many of whom have already been engaged in 3Pumpkins’ community development programme Let’s Go PLay Outside!, a joint partnership with South Central Community Family Service Centre since April 2019. Our programmes are carefully designed to build upon one another to enable sustainability in the long run.

Our work also encourages the community to step up. Recognising our effort and commitment to engage the children with very limited resources, the neighbourhood coffeeshop has stepped up and offered to sponsor a shop space for the exhibition. This signifies a positive start to how members of the community, or the community eco-system, can come together to create a warm and inspiring place for our children to grow up in. 

 

Risks & Challenges

The project will only work if children decide to get involved and take the time to go around, create cameras and develop pictures. It is unlikely, but possible, that only few children get involved in the project. While we aim for an impact over at least 40 of the neighbourhood’s children, even one or 2 participants can make a difference. 


The pilot experiment shows that many of the children are excited by the project and will likely come and visit out of curiosity, will make cameras, and use the dark room more than once. Eventually, we are confident that we can create a library of over 100 photographs of the neighborhood, people, bicycles, playground, building, trees, communities…

 

Other Ways You Can Help


Do you like the campaign but cannot contribute financially? You can still support this campaign by sharing widely! This will help the project become known, and make it more meaningful. Children will be very excited to learn that their project and photographs are reaching not just beyond their neighbourhood to reach the rest of Singapore, but hopefully throughout the world too.
story_txt:
Short SummaryThis campaign is run Isabelle Desjeux, an artist, working in collaboration with 3Pumpkins, a non-profitarts company working with communities.Isabelle has been playing with pinhole photography for the past 5 years. As she also regularly works with children, she has developed ways and methods to share the technique with children and families. This project aims to empower the children by teaching them how to make their own camera, take pictures of their neighbourhood and share the result.The Pin-Hole Photography in the Neighbourhood Project is co-created with children from Lengkok Bahru as part of a community placemaking project, Seeing The Obvious, where we explore different uses and designs of public spaces to connect people. When you contribute to this project, you help fulfill a dream children did not even know they had: to independently become photographers of their own neighbourhood, open up interest into a simple yet effective technology, spend time on an open-ended project, become an active part of their community as connectors, documenters, facilitators. And they will be so proud when their photographs are exhibited at the end, showing their work not just to their own community but to the public at large! What You Will Be Contributing ToThis is what we need:
A space. The King of Fruits shop has already been sponsored by the boss of the neighbourhood coffeeshop.Yay!
Dark Room set-up and consumables.This is where children will be loading their camera before stepping out to take a picture and coming back to develop it. The room might also function as a pin-hole camera body itself, where viewers can walk in and find themselves literally inside a camera box. Consumables are Photo paper, Developer and fixative. $500
Artist and Facilitator Fees. Between 17th January to 21th February, the space will be open to children who want to learn the technique, get help making their camera, or get support taking their picture. 2 adults will be present in the space for this time period, daily from approximately 3 pm till 6 pm. $2000
Exhibition set-up. The exhibition will take place from 15th February till 21st February. We will need to cover the cost of printing, framing, lighting, window text decals, as well as an augmented reality part. $500
If we don’t reach our full goal, we will run the show on a shoestring and simplify the project. If more funds are received, it could make the project sustainable by funding the project in neighbourhoods such as Boon Lay Drive, where 3Pumpkins is also reaching out to underserved children and youth in the neighbourhood.Rewards:We have gathered a number of perks ranging from collectable artwork to experiences. story:
Hi, we're Brian and Corrine Vegter

We love our community and Eastern Oregon.

To fund this endeavor, we sold our home and studio in downtown Baker City and have spent nearly every penny we have to get it all started. So far many friends and family members have put in 500+ volunteer hours painting, scrubbing, putting up dry wall, hauling, digging... cheering. Our community is already growing around the restoration of the school. 

For more than 11 years, we've used our event managing and art skills to create the region's annual We Like 'Em Short Film Festival, Feed the Hungry 5k Turkey Trot and the Baker City Cycling Classic.  We purchased the historic Churchill School, some folks thought we were crazy, with the hope of bringing it back to life and turning it into a community asset once again.

After sitting vacant for years, we feel it's time to bring life and possibility back to the nearly-a-century-old school. Our dream, with your help, will turn old classrooms into artist studios and galleries, the Cafetorium a performance space for all-ages concerts, film screening and plays, a place for couples to host wedding receptions or local organizations can put on special events, use the gym again for youth and adult sports.  Finally one classroom will house a bike/ski hostel. 

What We Need 

The Old School's immediate needs include:

  1. A new roof
  2. The windows restored
  3. A new boiler

Every dollar we raise through this crowdfunding will go to pay for these things. From our pockets, we've currently spent more than $60,000 to connect utilities (electricity, water and sewer) and repair the building – new dry wall, working toilets, debris removal and still only 1/3 of the school has working plumbing. We still need hundreds of thousands of dollars to save it. While we're applying for grants and doing small fundraisers, we really need your help to save this place.

Your contributions will go to restore Churchill School to its former glory and add a much needed performance venue and community space to Baker City. All money will be spent on "School Work."

Why help the "Old School"?

In addition to the warm feeling of building a community, you can get some sweet prizes. We created perks unique to this "Old School" and to fit any budget. Churchill School is one of the most beloved buildings in Baker City and we love this town and find it to be the most inspiring place we've ever lived. From getting your name on our concert guest list to riding a Big Wheel through the hallways to just being a encouraging supporter  – there's a great perk for your contribution.

Plus there are two Secret Perks!!!

We want present and future community member and visitors to be able to experience the Churchill School magic.

Even if we don't reach our $100,000 goal, we will put all dollars towards restoration while we search for other funding options

The Risk We're Taking 

We truly have sunk all our savings and available funds into this project and we know it's going to take years before we see any kind of return on our investment. As full time artists and event organizers we make very little money, but we always seem to get by. Since this is such a major undertaking, we've had to set aside our art for the past 4 months and have just been hemorrhaging our savings. 

What's made a huge impact in the short time we've owned Churchill is the number of people who've volunteered their time and talents. Since May an amazing number of hours by local volunteers, the Southwest Church of Christ (of Tigard, OR), and friends and family from across the US have been logged.

Not every project requires large sums of money, but they all take time. Whatever we can do ourselves, like fix toilets, repair drywall, replace broken glass, remove and replace water damaged siding and paint walls, we're doing it. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • We know not everyone can contribute $$ so follow us on Facebook and you can come to some of our volunteer work days. https://www.facebook.com/Churchill-School-Baker...
  •  You can also use Indiegogo share tools to let your friends know we're working to bring the amazing Churchill School back to life!

story:
LADYBUG LAND

The Lodge • The Barn • The Coop •  The Grounds

We bought a Lodge! And now, we need your help to renovate it so we can transform our corner of Cochecton Center, NY into a creative community campus for workshops, residencies, retreats, and more! 

Hi! Odetta and Camellia here. For over thirty years, our family home, fondly nicknamed The Ladybug House, has been a beacon of community and creativity for hundreds of guests from all over the world. The global pandemic of 2020 further revealed the value of communal gathering, the abundance of the land around us, and the myriad ways in which we can share resources with the world at large. A seed planted in quarantine turned into something much bigger, a dream sculpted by the minds and hands that supported the revival of our property and the surrounding land....

Our storied history is blossoming into a vibrant collective future, and we need your help to develop the missing piece - lodging - that will allow us to open up this space to artists and creators across all mediums. Read on for the backstory of our magical hamlet - your bucolic backyard escape awaits you, just 2.5 hours from NYC!

the LODGE - At long last, we have secured our guest house! With 7 bedrooms, 2 kitchens, a library common space, an outdoor patio plus an acre of green space totally secluded from the road, the Lodge will make it possible for us to host all kinds of groups for residencies, retreats, workshops, and special events. This space will be designed to host a wide array of needs, including but not limited to: band rehearsals; artist residencies (writers, studio artists, dancers, et al); team-building for professional development; skill shares and educational workshops; special celebrations, events, and gatherings for families and friends. Each room will be furnished and equipped with love and care that reflects the rich history and culture of our creative community that surrounds this space.

the GROUNDS - Our campus offers an escape from city life and an immersive opportunity to connect with nature as a source of inspiration. As stewards of this land, we have cultivated gardens & orchards between the banks of the 10-Mile River and our backyard creek. With a commitment to environmental conservation, we honor the traditional territory of the Lenni-Lenape tribe by growing native plants to encourage cross - pollination of species & ideas. Guests will be invited to learn about the native ecosystems and participate in its cultivation, enjoying seasonal activities like tapping maple syrup or harvesting produce from the gardens.

the BARN - Our 19th century barn found new life as a DIY recording studio in the coldest, darkest days of COVID. Beyond the potential for music rehearsal and recording, we have envisioned this wide, open space as a modular backdrop for events, workshops, content creation, and more.

the COOP - As our community has organically grown, so has our need for supplementary lodging. The first major project in Ladybug Land was renovating our chicken coop into a stand-alone guest cottage, designed with visiting writers and poets in mind.

How You Can Help

We need your support to restore these historic structures and get the doors open for all the magic you will bring!

  • Our goal of $150,000 will enable the full restoration of the LODGE, the essential & final component of this campus dream. This includes:

    • Complete renovation of (2) KITCHENS ($25,000)

    • Refurbished plumbing and installation of (4) BATHROOMS ($25,000)

    • Renovation and design of (7) BEDROOMS, (1) DINING ROOM, (1) LIVING ROOM/LIBRARY, and (2) OUTDOOR PATIOS ($25,000)

    • Updated electricity and HVAC (heating/cooling) systems ($50,000)

  • We have such a bounty to share already; all contributions will either reap immediate rewards or be an advanced payment of a future service! 
  • Any extra funds will help refurbish the other enchanting spaces in Ladybug Land! Every penny raised will go towards improving our campus and kickstarting our community initiatives. 

LOVELINESS: noun, a group of ladybugs 

It is truly a blessing to be surrounded by so many gifted, talented, and generous people, and our lives have revolved around amplifying our community, at concerts, birthdays, fundraisers, you name it. As we leap into this new chapter, our mission is to continue creating space for like-minded individuals to gather and work together, through sustainable practices and artistic pursuits. 

 

Projected Challenges & Other Ways You Can Help

There's a lot of work ahead and we welcome contributions in all shapes & sizes. If you are interested in getting involved with this vision but are unable to chip in financially, we are always going to need help with building, landscaping, design, planning, etc. Share this campaign with someone who might be interested, and let us know if you ever want to get your hands dirty in Ladybug Land!

From the bottom of our hearts - thank you thank you thank you!!!!

Camellia & Odetta

story:
Hi, I’m Marc, of Buffalo Bike Tours.

As a Buffalo Native who recently returned, I was blown away by how much the city has changed and all there is to see and do. Buffalo is home to a resurgent culture, world-class food, an amazing biking community, and some of the most endearing people anywhere.

While I love being back in my hometown, I noticed that most local tour offerings left a lot to be desired. Downtown was full of party bikes, double decker buses, and dry architectural tours – but I saw a need to create a tour company that would stand out with true authenticity. I had no money or investors – just passion for two of my favorite things: bikes and Buffalo.

I started leading free, donation-based tours. I wrote songs, brought poems to read, shared jokes, and showed people some of my favorite places while breaking down some of Buffalo’s negative perceptions. Much to my surprise, it worked! More than 250+ people showed up and we realized just maybe we're on to something.

2019 promises to be much, much bigger.

This year we're excited to partner with GObike, our bike advocacy organization, to offer bike rentals. We're taking 8 bikes destined for the landfill – and going to be refurbishing them and decking them out with decals, lights, and helmets. Tourists and locals alike will then be able to check them out from Buffalo-Niagara Hostel, where all tours will depart from and return to.

Moreover, we're offering more tours at more times, including:

B/Sides Ride: Buffalo’s Unsung History
Explore the deep cuts from Buffalo history – from civil rights to workers’ unrest – and how these movements have shaped the city today.

A/Sides Ride: The Best of Buffalo
Bike through parks while learning about Buffalo’s heavy hitters – from wild Erie Canal stories to the Pan American Exposition and the city’s world-class architecture.

The Wing Ride: The Classic Buffalo Foodie Experience
Earn your wings on this fresh trail through Buffalo’s tastiest restaurants and watering holes – with samples at 5 wide-ranging eateries.

East Meets West Ride: An International Foodie Experience
An epic meal on bikes connecting the city’s history to its current immigrant communities through the lens of its culinary traditions.

What your backing means.

Our tours provide one more reason to stay in Buffalo. It is our aim to get people exploring our many great neighborhoods. We want people not just to come to Buffalo as a stopping point on their way to Niagara Falls but to extend their stays. This means more support for our local business community – and all done on bikes!

 

We're asking for community buy-in.

In order to make our needed leap, we'll need at least $5,000. This will cover the following:

  • $2,500 - for fully refurbishing a fleet of 8 bikes.
  • $1,000 - for a lean online advertising budget.
  • $1,000 - for collateral including rack cards, posters, business cards, and website.
  • $500 - for legal and incorporating expenses.

    What's in it for me?

    We have some great perks for your support – including advance tickets to tours, locally-made merch, and incentives such as naming rights. So, be a part of our story, and save your spot on a tour before they fill up. Every bit helps!

    When do we get to party?

    The campaign will run for a month and culminate with Buffalo Bike Tours May’den Voyage on May 1, from 5:30PM-7:30PM, departing from GObike Community Workshop (98 Colvin Avenue). Everyone is welcome, and bike floats and costumes are encouraged. The community celebration will feature the debut of Buffalo Bike Tours new fleet of bikes, performances by the Buffalo Ukulele Club, a short talk about the history of May Day by historian Chris Hawley, a ribbon cutting ceremony, 6-mile bike parade to Hostel Buffalo-Niagara, and adult beverages. For more information, please see the Facebook event page.

    Risks & Challenges

    We know how to make the best out of our resources and we’re certain we will be successful in making good on what we’ve promised. We have full confidence in our accomplished and knowledgeable project team, their ability to meet key deadlines and their capacity to overcome potential challenges. Our risks are small – but if you have any questions, drop us a line! We can't do this without you :)

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Don't have the cash? There are other ways you can help, including:

    • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
    • Use the Indiegogo share tools.
    • Head on over to our website for more info.
    • Sign up to like us on Facebook and follow us on Instagram.
    • Join us for the start of our season on May 1st!

$1,000 - for collateral including rack cards, posters, business cards, and website.
$500 - for legal and incorporating expenses.


What's in it for me?
We have some great perks for your support – including advance tickets to tours, locally-made merch, and incentives such as naming rights. So, be a part of our story, and save your spot on a tour before they fill up. Every bit helps!
When do we get to party?
The campaign will run for a month and culminate with Buffalo Bike Tours May’den Voyage on May 1, from 5:30PM-7:30PM, departing from GObike Community Workshop (98 Colvin Avenue). Everyone is welcome, and bike floats and costumes are encouraged. The community celebration will feature the debut of Buffalo Bike Tours new fleet of bikes, performances by the Buffalo Ukulele Club, a short talk about the history of May Day by historian Chris Hawley, a ribbon cutting ceremony, 6-mile bike parade to Hostel Buffalo-Niagara, and adult beverages. For more information, please see the Facebook event page.


Risks & Challenges
We know how to make the best out of our resources and we’re certain we will be successful in making good on what we’ve promised. We have full confidence in our accomplished and knowledgeable project team, their ability to meet key deadlines and their capacity to overcome potential challenges. Our risks are small – but if you have any questions, drop us a line! We can't do this without you :)
Other Ways You Can Help
Don't have the cash? There are other ways you can help, including:

Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
Use the Indiegogo share tools.
Head on over to our website for more info.
Sign up to like us on Facebook and follow us on Instagram.
Join us for the start of our season on May 1st!

story:
Who are we?

The Falls of Clyde was built in 1878 (in Port Glasgow) and was one of eight sister ships named after the waterfalls of Scotland. She is now the sole survivor and is currently afloat in Honolulu, Hawaii. However, she is more than just a piece of Scottish history and heritage, she is a testament to the power of Scottish Shipbuilding as, after over 139 years, she is still steady and still floating.

But, there's a problem, she has fallen into disrepair and the Hawaiian authorities had planned to sink her. Our Glasgow based group 'Save Falls of Clyde International' campaign was formed -  by David O'Neill  - with the aim of stopping her being sunk and bringing her home to Scotland to be rebuilt and sailing again. After lengthy negotiations, we have managed to convince them to work with us to help bring her home and rebuild her so she can sail around the world again and we have ambitious plans for her (as detailed below).

We need your help!

By donating whatever you can, we can raise enough money to bring her back to Scotland. We have been in lengthy talks and have come to an agreement with a lift ship company who are prepared to offer a contract to bring her back in March 2019 and we are attempting to raise half of the full balance and by helping us do this, you will ensure her future.

We need £550k ($720k) to book the lift ship that will bring her home (this is half of the entire lift ship bill) and anything raised above this target will go towards the final lift ship bill, repair and rebuild costs. If we don't reach our target, we will use the money to try and negotiate a new deal with the lift ship company and if this fails (and she is ultimately sunk) we will donate the money to homeless charities in Scotland and Hawaii. However, we are confident that everyone will dig deep to help us meet the target.

Any funds raised above the £1.35 million ($1.5 million) needed for the lift ship will contribute towards her restoration.

The Impact

As well as a ship that is steeped in history and heritage, she will have several other roles :

Helping the poorest of our communities

We want to help the most underprivileged kids from our communities and take them on the trip of a lifetime. For 9 months of the year, we will be teaching them onboard with our 'education at sea' program (via fully qualified teaching staff and crew) and help them grow, mature and give them hope for a brighter future as they experience new cultures and see the world. 

Fairtrade Cargo

We plan to carry Fairtrade cargo such as rum, whiskey, chocolate and coffee (to name but a few) and help communities all over the world, ensuring farmers and workers are paid a living wage and that their children are able to go to school. We also want to teach the kids onboard about these communities, getting them involved with all the steps and processes and helping them strengthen relationships and make lifelong friends. We have further plans to set up a fair trade project from Scotland - becoming a carbon-free sail powered cargo service.

Ocean waste and plastic collection, cleanup and recycling

Plastic in our oceans is a huge problem and we plan to put the Falls to good use by fitting with the latest technology available and cleaning up the ocean as she sails. We will clean-up, recycle and collect the plastics from our oceans and have several promising plans in place to make this happen. 

Carbon Free/neutral technology

We plan to fit her with the latest 'green' technology (including renewable energy such as solar, electric and - of course - wind power) to ensure that she remains carbon free/neutral. Becoming a role model for the rest of the world and trailblazing the latest green technology - the world will be following in our wake!  

Sail training

We want everyone to get a chance to sail on this beautiful ship and, during certain times of the year, we will have space on board for sailing adventures. Letting the public experience life on the big blue ocean and helping them reach their full potential, reaching heights they never thought possible.

History and Heritage

During her rebuild phase (and beyond) we have plans to build a museum and genealogy centre around the harbour where she is being rebuilt. Here people can learn about the history of ship building, the history of the 'Falls Of Clyde' and genealogy; helping us understand the world around us. 

Once restored, we are also considering reinstatement of the once famous 'Tea Races' culminating on the Clyde. Challenging other tall ships globally and showing them why Clyde built remains the best built.

Self sustaining ship

All of the duties listed above will ensure that the ship will be self sustaining whilst making an impact and putting Scotland firmly on the map in terms of technology, social and community causes and ensuring that we give the future generations hope for the future.

Risks & Challenges

There is always risk with a project as large as this. Not raising enough money and the ship being deliberately sunk is the biggest risk at the moment as we are on a tight deadline and the Hawaiian authorities have given us a limited time to complete this task. She also needs to be repaired and getting her onto the lift ship will be a delicate operation.

In order to overcome these risks, we are continually updating the Hawaiian authorities and being as transparent as possible about any problems we face to ensure a strong working relationship continues and they continue to cooperate in getting her home. There have also been several naval architect reports done and all of them have come to the same conclusion that she can be repaired and would be able to sail again. 

Furthermore, we are continually talking with the lift ship company and they are confident that this operation can be completed with minimal risk to the ship. We are also continually negotiating with councils back in Scotland, ensuring she has a place to come home to. This has, at times, proven difficult but by building trust and developing relationships, we are now very much underway and, presently, she is heading back to Troon to for the first stage of her repairs.

Finally, the bill to bring her home and restore her was originally much higher (to just bring her home was costing around £3.8 million - $5 million -) but we have managed to bring the price down to a more realistic target and are actively engaging with various companies and trades to bring the repair costs down further.

The next phase

We are aware that we are only asking for half of the money needed to bring her back home but even though we plan to raise as much money as we can via crowdfunding platforms (through the incredible generosity of you guys!) we plan to raise further funding through a commercial sponsorship campaign during her journey home. 

We are currently planning to launch the commercial sponsorship campaign for global companies to gain brand exposure during her journey home. We have been talking with media stations all around the world about covering this journey and we are confident she will be well covered through TV, social media and radio which, in turn, will mean people will see the company's logos emblazoned on our 'temporary' sails (see the plan below)- this will help us raise more of the money needed to help rebuild her and get her sailing again. The branding will also be present during the several stops we have planned on her journey home and the final bonanza (spanning the length of the Clyde) on her return to Scotland. Furthermore, we have been advised that part of the funding could come from various social and lottery funds but, without your help, none of this will happen as we need to get her back home (in UK waters) first in order to qualify for this type of funding. We are confident that if we can raise enough money to get her home, we can raise the rest of the money needed to restore her as we also have innovative ideas around engaging with suppliers and skill sets and these ideas have been positively received. This, in turn, will help reduce the overall cost of her rebuild.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate financially, don't worry, we understand! There are still plenty of ways you can help:

  • Spread the word - tell everyone you know (and even the odd stranger) about our campaign, shout it from the rooftops and share, share, share! From Facebook to Twitter - tell the world!
  • Volunteer - do you have a specific set of skills you think would be useful? Even if you just want to donate your time, get in touch, we are always happy to hear from you! You can contact us on savefallsofclyde@gmail.com
  • P.A.R.T.Y! - Come along to the huge parties throughout her journey to celebrate her coming home. We have planned several stops from Hawaii with a massive party planned (all along the Clyde) when she returns to Scotland. Great food, great drink and great entertainment - showing the world why Scotland is the friendliest nation on earth.
  • Flotilla-ing along nicely - we are also planning to attempt a world record for the biggest flotilla on the Clyde - if you have a yacht, boat, dingy, rowing boat (or even a floating plank of wood!) then get in touch to find out more about how you can be part of this huge record breaker!

If you require more information on the project or its progress, you can find out more on our facebook page www.facebook.com/savefallsofclyde or contact us on the above email (savefallsofclyde@gmail.com)

story:
(PARA ESPAÑOL, VEA MAS ABAJO)

In the face of death we are all equal, we are all “Calacas”. This is the idea that inspired the La Calaca Festival and this is why it is free and open to the entire community of San Miguel de Allende during the Day of the Dead celebrations. To preserve and promote this beautiful tradition, we need your help!

This communal projected memorial will raise the funds necessary to cost the multiple high resolution projectors, and all the technology and logistics needed to pull off a piece of work of these dimentions

Obviously we can't do it all for $5000, but the more we exceed our modest goal, the more exciting programming we can offer to the community.

Why a public, collective video memorial is impactful.

This projected communal projection mapping memorial will be seen by thousands of people who will be moved to remember their loved ones who have passed, and others whom they admired and respected.

We wish to honor the victims of the earthquakes that have shaken the spirits of the Mexican people and the global community. We do not wish to burden the town with solicitations for funds when funding is so scarce in the wake of this tragedy. La Calaca is known for its resourcefulness, year after year (it was founded in 2012) despite the tiny budgets we have had to work with.

Please share this campaign with your friends!

The more people who contribute a video or still image honoring someone special, the more impactful the installation will become. And the more funding we will have to move the hearts of the community during this profound traditional holiday, which is beginning to be recognized as a relevant celebration the world over. So thank you for sharing this campaign far and wide (Indiegogo share tools make it easy). It feels good to honor people we care about, and we amplify how impactful these people were in your life in a beautiful, crowd-sourced way in one of the most magnificent towns in the world. So please donate via the perk and email a high resolution image to Tomas Burkey: <baalamix@gmail.com> today!

Andalé Calacas!

www.lacalacafestival.com

https://www.facebook.com/LaCalacaFestival/

EN ESPAÑOL:

Homenaje Memorial Colectivo de La Calaca

Rinde tributo a algún ser amado durante el Día de Muertos en el mágico San Miguel de Allende, México.

Deseas honrar alguien que haya fallecido?  O te gustaría rendir homenaje a alguien que admiraste? El Festival La Calaca le invita a aportar una imagen fija o un video corto para que sea proyectado en un muro exterior en el centro de esta mágica ciudad Patrimonio de la Humanidad durante la semana de  Día de Muertos del 1ro al 4 de noviembre.

HISTORIA

Ante la muerte todos somos iguales, todos somos "Calacas". Esta es la idea que inspiró el Festival  La Calaca y por eso es gratuita y abierta a toda la comunidad de San Miguel de Allende durante las celebraciones del Día de Muertos.  Para preservar y promover esta hermosa tradición, necesitamos su ayuda!

Este monumento comunitario ayudará a reunir los fondos necesarios para los equipos necesarios incluyendo múltiples proyectores de altissima calidad, y toda la tecnologia y logistica necesaria para ejecutar esta pieza monumental.

Obviamente no podemos hacer todo lo anterior con $ 5000 usd, pero cuanto más excedamos nuestro modesto objetivo, más actividades y programas podremos ofrecer a la comunidad.

Por qué un Homenaje Público en Video tiene un gran impacto?

Este monumento comunitario conmemorativo en proyección será visto por miles de personas que serán conmovidos y recordarán a sus seres queridos que han fallecido, ya otros a quienes admiraron y respetaron.

Queremos honrar a las víctimas de los terremotos que han sacudido a los espíritus del pueblo mexicano ya la comunidad global. No queremos cargar la ciudad con solicitudes de fondos cuando la financiación es tan escasa a raíz de esta tragedia. La Calaca es conocida por su capacidad de generar recursos, año tras año (fue fundada en 2012) a pesar de los pequeños presupuestos con los que hemos venido trabajando.

Comparte esta campaña con tus amigos!

Cuanta más gente aporte un video o imagen fija en honor a alguien especial, más impactante será la instalación. Y a la vez tendremos más fondos para mover los corazones de la comunidad durante estas profundas fiestas tradicionales, que comienzan a ser reconocidas como una celebración relevante en todo el mundo. Así que, gracias por compartir esta campaña a lo largo y ancho (las herramientas para compartir de Indiegogo lo hacen fácil). Se siente bien honrar a la gente que nos importa, y amplificar cuan impactantes fueron estas personas en nuestras vidas de una manera hermosa y colaborativa, en una de las ciudades más magníficas del mundo.

Ándale Calaca!

//RECOMPENSAS

$ 25 USD (aprox. $450 pesos)

Imagen  conmemorativo

Participa en nuestro monumento colectivo enviando una fotografía de alguien que haya fallecido a quien quieras homenajear. Si envías una fotografía o un video sin sonido, incluye el nombre del difunto, y tal vez una cita o frase, y / o los años que vivieron. Envia su imagen a Tomas Burkey <baalamix@gmail.com>
